d:entry.p: CFWheels (ColdFusion on Wheels) is an open-source ColdFusion (CFML) framework inspired by Ruby on Rails.
It provides fast application development, a great organization system for code, and is just plain fun to use.
Start by looking at the CFWheels API.
To find out more, go to http://cfwheels.org/
Use this method to specify which properties can be set through mass assignment.

tr.td: Property name (or list of property names) that are allowed to be altered through mass assignment.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, only `isActive` can be set through mass assignment operations like `updateAll()` ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset accessibleProperties("isActive")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Adds the default Wheels routes (for example, `[controller]/[action]/[key]`, etc.) to your application. Only use this method if you have set `loadDefaultRoutes` to `false` and want to control exactly where in the route order you want to place the default routes.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Adds the default routes to your application (done in `config/routes.cfm`) ---> <cfset addDefaultRoutes()>

d:entry.p: Adds an error on a specific property.

tr.td: The name of the property you want to add an error on.
The error message (such as "Please enter a correct name in the form field" for example).
A name to identify the error by (useful when you need to distinguish one error from another one set on the same object and you don't want to use the error message itself for that).

code.pre: <!--- Add an error to the `email` property ---> <cfset this.addError(property="email", message="Sorry, you are not allowed to use that email. Try again, please.")>

d:entry.p: Adds an error on the object as a whole (not related to any specific property).

tr.td: The error message (such as "Please enter a correct name in the form field" for example).
A name to identify the error by (useful when you need to distinguish one error from another one set on the same object and you don't want to use the error message itself for that).

code.pre: <!--- Add an error on the object ---> <cfset this.addErrorToBase(message="Your email address must be the same as your domain name.")>

d:entry.p: Adds a new MIME format to your Wheels application for use with responding to multiple formats.

tr.td: Matching MIME type to associate with the file extension.

code.pre:
<!--- Add the `js` format ---> <cfset addFormat(extension="js", mimeType="text/javascript")>
<!--- Add the `ppt` and `pptx` formats ---> <cfset addFormat(extension="ppt", mimeType="application/vnd.ms-powerpoint")> <cfset addFormat(extension="pptx", mimeType="application/vnd.ms-powerpoint")>

d:entry.p: Adds a new route to your application.

tr.td: Name for the route. This is referenced as the `name` argument in functions based on @URLFor like @linkTo, @startFormTag, etc.
The URL pattern that the route will match.
Controller to call when route matches (unless the controller name exists in the pattern).
Action to call when route matches (unless the action name exists in the pattern).

code.pre:
<!--- Example 1: Adds a route which will invoke the `profile` action on the `user` controller with `params.userName` set when the URL matches the `pattern` argument ---> <cfset addRoute(name="userProfile", pattern="user/[username]", controller="user", action="profile")>
<!--- Example 2: Category/product URLs. Note the order of precedence is such that the more specific route should be defined first so Wheels will fall back to the less-specific version if it's not found ---> <cfset addRoute(name="product", pattern="products/[categorySlug]/[productSlug]", controller="products", action="product")> <cfset addRoute(name="productCategory", pattern="products/[categorySlug]", controller="products", action="category")> <cfset addRoute(name="products", pattern="products", controller="products", action="index")>
<!--- Example 3: Change the `home` route. This should be listed last because it is least specific ---> <cfset addRoute(name="home", pattern="", controller="main", action="index")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after a new object is created.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterCreate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an object is deleted.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterDelete("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an existing object has been initialized (which is usually done with the @findByKey or @findOne method).

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre:
<!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `setTime` method after getting objects or records with one of the finder methods ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset afterFind("setTime")> </cffunction>
<cffunction name="setTime"> <cfset arguments.fetchedAt = Now()> <cfreturn arguments> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an object has been initialized.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterInitialization("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after a new object has been initialized (which is usually done with the @new method).

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterNew("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an object is saved.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterSave("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an existing object is updated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterUpdate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterValidation("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after a new object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterValidationOnCreate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called after an existing object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset afterValidationOnUpdate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Returns a struct detailing all changes that have been made on the object but not yet saved to the database.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, change it, and then ask for its changes (will return a struct containing the changes, both property names and their values) ---> <cfset member = model("member").findByKey(params.memberId)> <cfset member.firstName = params.newFirstName> <cfset member.email = params.newEmail> <cfset allChanges = member.allChanges()>

d:entry.p: Returns an array of all the errors on the object.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get all the errors for the `user` object ---> <cfset errorInfo = user.allErrors()>

d:entry.p: Turns all URLs and email addresses into hyperlinks.

tr.td: The text to create links in.
Whether to link URLs, email addresses or both. Possible values are: `all` (default), `URLs` and `emailAddresses`.

code.pre: #autoLink("Download Wheels from http://cfwheels.org/download")# -> Download Wheels from http://cfwheels.org/download #autoLink("Email us at info@cfwheels.org")# -> Email us at info@cfwheels.org

d:entry.p: Whether or not to enable default validations for this model.
None.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, disable automatic validations. In this case, automatic validations are probably enabled globally, but we want to disable just for this model ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset automaticValidations(false)> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Calculates the average value for a given property. Uses the SQL function `AVG`. If no records can be found to perform the calculation on you can use the `ifNull` argument to decide what should be returned.

code.span: average(property [, where, include, distinct, parameterize, ifNull, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Name of the property to calculate the average for.

This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
When `true`, `AVG` will be performed only on each unique instance of a value, regardless of how many times the value occurs.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
The value returned if no records are found. Common usage is to set this to `0` to make sure a numeric value is always returned instead of a blank string.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the average salary for all employees ---> <cfset avgSalary = model("employee").average("salary")>
<!--- Get the average salary for employees in a given department ---> <cfset avgSalary = model("employee").average(property="salary", where="departmentId=#params.key#")>
<!--- Make sure a numeric value is always returned if no records are calculated ---> <cfset avgSalary = model("employee").average(property="salary", where="salary BETWEEN #params.min# AND #params.max#", ifNull=0>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before a new object is created.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeCreate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before an object is deleted.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeDelete("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before an object is saved.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeSave("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before an existing object is updated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeUpdate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before an object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeValidation("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before a new object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeValidationOnCreate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called before an existing object is validated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names that should be called when this callback event occurs in an object's life cycle (can also be called with the `method` argument).

code.pre: <!--- Instruct Wheels to call the `fixObj` method ---> <cfset beforeValidationOnUpdate("fixObj")>

d:entry.p: Sets up a `belongsTo` association between this model and the specified one. Use this association when this model contains a foreign key referencing another model.

tr.td: Gives the association a name that you refer to when working with the association (in the `include` argument to @findAll, to name one example).
Name of associated model (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions because the model name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Foreign key property name (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions since the foreign key name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Use to set the join type when joining associated tables. Possible values are `inner` (for `INNER JOIN`) and `outer` (for `LEFT OUTER JOIN`).

code.pre:
<!--- Specify that instances of this model belong to an author. (The table for this model should have a foreign key set on it, typically named `authorid`.) ---> <cfset belongsTo("author")>
<!--- Same as above, but because we have broken away from the foreign key naming convention, we need to set `modelName` and `foreignKey` ---> <cfset belongsTo(name="bookWriter", modelName="author", foreignKey="authorId")>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a button `form` control.

code.span: buttonTag([ content, type, image, value, disable ])

tr.td: Content to display inside the button.
The type for the button: `button`, `reset`, or `submit`.
File name of the image file to use in the button form control.
The value of the button when submitted.
Whether or not to disable the button upon clicking. (Prevents double-clicking.)

code.pre: <!--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #startFormTag(action="something")# <!--- form controls go here ---> #buttonTag(content="Submit this form", value="save")# #endFormTag()# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Creates a form containing a single button that submits to the URL. The URL is built the same way as the @linkTo function.

code.span: buttonTo([ text, confirm, image, disable, route, controller, action, key, params, anchor, onlyPath, host, protocol, port ])

tr.td: The text content of the button.
Pass a message here to cause a JavaScript confirmation dialog box to pop up containing the message.
If you want to use an image for the button pass in the link to it here (relative from the `images` folder).

Pass in `true` if you want the button to be disabled when clicked (can help prevent multiple clicks), or pass in a string if you want the button disabled and the text on the button updated (to "please wait...", for example).
Name of a route that you have configured in `config/routes.cfm`.
Name of the controller to include in the URL.
Name of the action to include in the URL.
Key(s) to include in the URL.
Any additional params to be set in the query string.
Sets an anchor name to be appended to the path.
If `true`, returns only the relative URL (no protocol, host name or port).
Set this to override the current host.
Set this to override the current protocol.
Set this to override the current port number.

code.pre: #buttonTo(text="Delete Account", action="perFormDelete", disable="Wait...")#

d:entry.p: Tells Wheels to cache one or more actions.

tr.td: Action(s) to cache. This argument is also aliased as `actions`.
Minutes to cache the action(s) for.

Set to `true` to tell Wheels that this is a static page and that it can skip running the controller filters (before and after filters set on actions) and application events (onSessionStart, onRequestStart etc).

code.pre: <cfset caches(actions="browseByUser,browseByTitle", time=30)>

d:entry.p: Returns the text with the first character converted to uppercase.

code.pre: <!--- Capitalize a sentence, will result in "Wheels is a framework" ---> #capitalize("wheels is a framework")#

d:entry.p: Returns the previous value of a property that has changed. Returns an empty string if no previous value exists. Wheels will keep a note of the previous property value until the object is saved to the database.

tr.td: Name of property to get the previous value for.

code.pre:
<!--- Get a member object and change the `email` property on it ---> <cfset member = model("member").findByKey(params.memberId)> <cfset member.email = params.newEmail>
<!--- Get the previous value (what the `email` property was before it was changed)---> <cfset oldValue = member.changedFrom("email")>
<!--- The above can also be done using a dynamic function like this ---> <cfset oldValue = member.emailChangedFrom()>

d:entry.p: Returns a list of the object properties that have been changed but not yet saved to the database.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, change it, and then ask for its changes (will return a list of the property names that have changed, not the values themselves) ---> <cfset member = model("member").findByKey(params.memberId)> <cfset member.firstName = params.newFirstName> <cfset member.email = params.newEmail> <cfset changedProperties = member.changedProperties()>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a check box form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. In most cases, this function generates a form field that should represent a `boolean` style field in your data. Use @checkBoxTag or @hasManyCheckBox to generate check boxes for selecting multiple values. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: checkBox(objectName, property [, association, position, checkedValue, uncheckedValue, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
The value of the check box when it's in the `checked` state.
The value of the check box when it's in the `unchecked` state.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
#checkBox(objectName="photo", property="isPublic", label="Display this photo publicly.")#

#user.photos[i].title#:

#checkBox(objectName="user", association="photos", position=i, property="isPublic", label="Display this photo publicly.")#

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a check box form control based on the supplied `name`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: checkBoxTag(name [, checked, value, uncheckedValue, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
Whether or not the check box should be checked by default.
Value of check box in its `checked` state.
The value of the check box when it's on the `unchecked` state.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre:
<!--- Example 1: Basic usage involves a `label`, `name`, and `value` ---> <cfoutput> #checkBoxTag(name="subscribe", value="true", label="Subscribe to our newsletter", checked=false)# </cfoutput>
<!--- Example 2: Loop over a query to display choices and whether or not they are checked ---> <!--- - Controller code ---> <cfset pizza = model("pizza").findByKey(session.pizzaId)> <cfset selectedToppings = pizza.toppings()> <cfset toppings = model("topping").findAll(order="name")>
<!--- View code ---> <fieldset> <legend>Toppings</legend> <cfoutput query="toppings"> #checkBoxTag(name="toppings", value="true", label=toppings.name, checked=YesNoFormat(ListFind(ValueList(selectedToppings.id), toppings.id))# </cfoutput> </fieldset>

d:entry.p: Clears out all errors set on the object or only the ones set for a specific property or name.

tr.td: Specify a property name here if you want to clear all errors set on that property.
Specify an error name here if you want to clear all errors set with that error name.

code.pre:
<!--- Clear all errors on the object as a whole ---> <cfset this.clearErrors()>
<!--- Clear all errors on `firstName` ---> <cfset this.clearErrors("firstName")>

d:entry.p: Returns a struct with data for the named property.

tr.td: Name of column to retrieve data for.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, set a value and then see if the property exists ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").new()> <cfset employee.columnDataForProperty("firstName")><!--- returns column struct --->

d:entry.p: Returns the column name mapped for the named model property.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, set a value and then see if the property exists ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").new()> <cfset employee.columnForProperty("firstName")><!--- returns column name, in this case "firstname" if the convention is used --->

d:entry.p: Returns a list of column names in the table mapped to this model. The list is ordered according to the columns' ordinal positions in the database table.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get a list of all the column names in the table mapped to the `author` model ---> <cfset columns = model("author").columnNames()>

d:entry.p: Returns an array of columns names for the table associated with this class. Does not include calculated properties that will be generated by the Wheels ORM.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get the columns names in the order they are in the database ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").columns()>

d:entry.p: Pass in another Wheels model object to see if the two objects are the same.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Load a user requested in the URL/form and restrict access if it doesn't match the user stored in the session ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(params.key)> <cfif not user.compareTo(session.user)> <cfset renderPage(action="accessDenied")> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Used to store a section's output for rendering within a layout. This content store acts as a stack, so you can store multiple pieces of content for a given section.

tr.td: The position in the section's stack where you want the content placed. Valid values are `first`, `last`, or the numeric position.
Whether or not to overwrite any of the content. Valid values are `false`, `true`, or `all`.

code.pre:
My Sidebar Text

 My Site #includeContent("sidebar")# #includeContent()#

d:entry.p: Includes content for the `body` section, which equates to the output generated by the view template run by the request.
None.

code.pre:
<!--- In `views/layout.cfm` ---> <html> <head> <title>My Site</title> </head>
<body> <cfoutput>#contentForLayout()#</cfoutput> </body>
</html>

d:entry.p: Creates and returns a controller object with your own custom `name` and `params`. Used primarily for testing purposes.

tr.td: Name of the controller to create.
The params struct (combination of `form` and `URL` variables).

code.pre: <cfset testController = controller("users", params)>

d:entry.p: Returns the number of rows that match the arguments (or all rows if no arguments are passed in). Uses the SQL function `COUNT`. If no records can be found to perform the calculation on, `0` is returned.

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Count how many authors there are in the table ---> <cfset authorCount = model("author").count()>
<!--- Count how many authors that have a last name starting with an "A" ---> <cfset authorOnACount = model("author").count(where="lastName LIKE 'A%'")>
<!--- Count how many authors that have written books starting with an "A" ---> <cfset authorWithBooksOnACount = model("author").count(include="books", where="booktitle LIKE 'A%'")>
<!--- Count the number of comments on a specific post (a `hasMany` association from `post` to `comment` is required) ---> <!--- The `commentCount` method will call `model("comment").count(where="postId=#post.id#")` internally ---> <cfset aPost = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset amount = aPost.commentCount()>

d:entry.p: Creates a new object, saves it to the database (if the validation permits it), and returns it. If the validation fails, the unsaved object (with errors added to it) is still returned. Property names and values can be passed in either using named arguments or as a struct to the `properties` argument.

code.span: create([ properties, parameterize, reload, transaction, callbacks ])

tr.td: The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set to `true` to reload the object from the database once an insert/update has completed.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre:
<!--- Create a new author and save it to the database ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").create(params.author)>
<!--- Same as above using named arguments ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").create(firstName="John", lastName="Doe")>
<!--- Same as above using both named arguments and a struct ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").create(active=1, properties=params.author)>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` or `hasMany` association setup from `customer` to `order`, you can do a scoped call. d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing three select form controls for month, day, and year based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`.

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.

String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

d:entry.p: Deletes the object, which means the row is deleted from the database (unless prevented by a `beforeDelete` callback). Returns `true` on successful deletion of the row, `false` otherwise.

code.span: delete([ parameterize, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes, softDelete ])

tr.td: Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.
Set to `false` to permanently delete a record, even if it has a soft delete column.

code.pre:
<!--- Get a post object and then delete it from the database ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(33)> <cfset post.delete()>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `deleteComment` method below will call `comment.delete()` internally.) ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset comment = model("comment").findByKey(params.commentId)> <cfset post.deleteComment(comment)>

d:entry.p: Deletes all records that match the `where` argument. By default, objects will not be instantiated and therefore callbacks and validations are not invoked. You can change this behavior by passing in `instantiate=true`. Returns the number of records that were deleted.

code.span: deleteAll([ where, include, reload, parameterize, instantiate, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes, softDelete ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Whether or not to instantiate the object(s) first. When objects are not instantiated, any callbacks and validations set on them will be skipped.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.
Set to `false` to permanently delete a record, even if it has a soft delete column.

code.pre:
<!--- Delete all inactive users without instantiating them (will skip validation and callbacks) ---> <cfset recordsDeleted = model("user").deleteAll(where="inactive=1", instantiate=false)>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `deleteAllComments` method below will call `model("comment").deleteAll(where="postId=#post.id#")` internally.) ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset howManyDeleted = post.deleteAllComments()>

d:entry.p: Finds the record with the supplied key and deletes it. Returns `true` on successful deletion of the row, `false` otherwise.

code.span: deleteByKey(key [, reload, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes, softDelete ])

tr.td: Primary key value(s) of the record to fetch. Separate with comma if passing in multiple primary key values. Accepts a string, list, or a numeric value.

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.
Set to `false` to permanently delete a record, even if it has a soft delete column.

code.pre: <!--- Delete the user with the primary key value of `1` ---> <cfset result = model("user").deleteByKey(1)>

d:entry.p: Gets an object based on conditions and deletes it.

code.span: deleteOne([ where, order, reload, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes, softDelete ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
Maps to the `ORDER BY` clause of the query. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.
Set to `false` to permanently delete a record, even if it has a soft delete column.

code.pre:
<!--- Delete the user that signed up last ---> <cfset result = model("user").deleteOne(order="signupDate DESC")>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` association setup from `user` to `profile` you can do a scoped call (the `deleteProfile` method below will call `model("profile").deleteOne(where="userId=#aUser.id#")` internally) ---> <cfset aUser = model("user").findByKey(params.userId)> <cfset aUser.deleteProfile()>

d:entry.p: Deobfuscates a value.

code.pre: <!--- Get the original value from an obfuscated one ---> <cfset originalValue = deobfuscateParam("b7ab9a50")>

d:entry.p: Pass in two dates to this method, and it will return a string describing the difference between them.

tr.td: Whether or not to include the number of seconds in the returned string.

code.pre: <cfset aWhileAgo = Now() - 30> <cfset rightNow = Now()> <cfoutput>#distanceOfTimeInWords(aWhileAgo, rightNow)#</cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing the closing `form` tag.
None.

code.pre: <!--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #startFormTag(action="create")# <!--- your form controls ---> #endFormTag()# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns the number of errors this object has associated with it. Specify `property` or `name` if you wish to count only specific errors.

tr.td: Specify a property name here if you want to count only errors set on a specific property.
Specify an error name here if you want to count only errors set with a specific error name.

code.pre:
<!--- Check how many errors are set on the object ---> <cfif author.errorCount() GTE 10> <!--- Do something to deal with this very erroneous author here... ---> </cfif>
<!--- Check how many errors are associated with the `email` property ---> <cfif author.errorCount("email") gt 0> <!--- Do something to deal with this erroneous author here... ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Returns the error message, if one exists, on the object's property. If multiple error messages exist, the first one is returned.

code.span: errorMessageOn(objectName, property [, prependText, appendText, wrapperElement, class ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to display the error message for.
The name of the property to display the error message for.
String to prepend to the error message.
String to append to the error message.
HTML element to wrap the error message in.
CSS class to set on the wrapper element.

code.pre: <!--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #errorMessageOn(objectName="user", property="email")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a list (`ul` tag with a class of `error-messages`) containing all the error messages for all the properties of the object (if any). Returns an empty string otherwise.

tr.td: The variable name of the object to display error messages for.
CSS class to set on the `ul` element.
Whether or not to show duplicate error messages.

code.pre: <!--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #errorMessagesFor(objectName="user")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns an array of all errors associated with the supplied property (and error name if passed in).

tr.td: Specify the property name to return errors for here.
If you want to return only errors on the above property set with a specific error name you can specify it here.

code.pre: <!--- Get all errors related to the email address of the user object ---> <cfset errors = user.errorsOn("emailAddress")>

d:entry.p: Returns an array of all errors associated with the object as a whole (not related to any specific property).

tr.td: Specify an error name here to only return errors for that error name.

code.pre: <!--- Get all general type errors for the user object ---> <cfset errors = user.errorsOnBase()>

d:entry.p: Extracts an excerpt from text that matches the first instance of a given phrase.

tr.td: The text to extract an excerpt from.
Number of characters to extract surrounding the phrase.
String to replace first and/or last characters with.

code.pre: #excerpt(text="ColdFusion Wheels is a Rails-like MVC framework for Adobe ColdFusion and Railo", phrase="framework", radius=5)# -> ... MVC framework for ...

d:entry.p: Checks if a record exists in the table. You can pass in either a primary key value to the `key` argument or a string to the `where` argument.

tr.td: Primary key value(s) of the record to fetch. Separate with comma if passing in multiple primary key values. Accepts a string, list, or a numeric value.

This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.

code.pre:
<!--- Checking if Joe exists in the database ---> <cfset result = model("user").exists(where="firstName='Joe'")>
<!--- Checking if a specific user exists based on a primary key valued passed in through the URL/form in an if statement ---> <cfif model("user").exists(keyparams.key)> <!--- Do something... ---> </cfif>
<!--- If you have a `belongsTo` association setup from `comment` to `post`, you can do a scoped call. (The `hasPost` method below will call `model("post").exists(comment.postId)` internally.) ---> <cfset comment = model("comment").findByKey(params.commentId)> <cfset commentHasAPost = comment.hasPost()>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` association setup from `user` to `profile`, you can do a scoped call. (The `hasProfile` method below will call `model("profile").exists(where="userId=#user.id#")` internally.) ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(params.userId)> <cfset userHasProfile = user.hasProfile()>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `hasComments` method below will call `model("comment").exists(where="postid=#post.id#")` internally.) ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset postHasComments = post.hasComments()>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a file field form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: fileField(objectName, property [, association, position, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
<!--- Provide a `label` and the required `objectName` and `property` ---> <cfoutput> #fileField(label="Photo", objectName="photo", property="imageFile")# </cfoutput>
<!--- Display fields for photos provided by the `screenshots` association and nested properties ---> <fieldset> <legend>Screenshots</legend> <cfloop from="1" to="#ArrayLen(site.screenshots)#" index="i"> #fileField(label="File ##i#", objectName="site", association="screenshots", position=i, property="file")# #textField(label="Caption ##i#", objectName="site", association="screenshots", position=i, property="caption")# </cfloop> </fieldset>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a file form control based on the supplied `name`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: fileFieldTag(name [, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

d:entry.p: Returns an array of all the filters set on this controller in the order in which they will be executed.

tr.td: Use this argument to return only `before` or `after` filters.

code.pre: <!--- Get filter chain, remove the first item, and set it back ---> <cfset myFilterChain = filterChain()> <cfset ArrayDeleteAt(myFilterChain, 1)> <cfset setFilterChain(myFilterChain)>

d:entry.p: Tells Wheels to run a function before an action is run or after an action has been run. You can also specify multiple functions and actions.

tr.td: Function(s) to execute before or after the action(s).
Whether to run the function(s) before or after the action(s).
Pass in a list of action names (or one action name) to tell Wheels that the filter function(s) should only be run on these actions.
Pass in a list of action names (or one action name) to tell Wheels that the filter function(s) should be run on all actions except the specified ones.

code.pre:
<!--- Always execute `restrictAccess` before all actions in this controller ---> <cfset filters("restrictAccess")>
<!--- Always execute `isLoggedIn` and `checkIPAddress` (in that order) before all actions in this controller except the `home` and `login` actions ---> <cfset filters(through="isLoggedIn,checkIPAddress", except="home,login")>

d:entry.p: Returns records from the database table mapped to this model according to the arguments passed in. (Use the `where` argument to decide which records to get, use the `order` argument to set in what order those records should be returned, and so on). The records will be returned as either a `cfquery` result set or an array of objects (depending on what the `returnAs` argument is set to). Instead of using the `where` argument, you can create cleaner code by making use of a concept called dynamic finders.

code.span: findAll([ where, order, group, select, distinct, include, maxRows, page, perPage, count, handle, cache, reload, parameterize, returnAs, returnIncluded, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
Maps to the `ORDER BY` clause of the query. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
Maps to the `GROUP BY` clause of the query. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Determines how the `SELECT` clause for the query used to return data will look. You can pass in a list of the properties (which map to columns) that you want returned from your table(s). If you don't set this argument at all, Wheels will select all properties from your table(s). If you specify a table name (e.g. `users.email`) or alias a column (e.g. `fn AS firstName`) in the list, then the entire list will be passed through unchanged and used in the `SELECT` clause of the query. By default, all column names in tables `JOIN`ed via the `include` argument will be prepended with the singular version of the included table name.

Whether to add the `DISTINCT` keyword to your `SELECT` clause. Wheels will, when necessary, add this automatically (when using pagination and a `hasMany` association is used in the `include` argument, to name one example).

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
Maximum number of records to retrieve. Passed on to the `maxRows` `cfquery` attribute. The default, `-1`, means that all records will be retrieved.

If you want to paginate records, you can do so by specifying a page number here. For example, getting records 11-20 would be page number 2 when `perPage` is kept at the default setting (10 records per page). The default, `0`, means that records won't be paginated and that the `perPage`, `count`, and `handle` arguments will be ignored.
When using pagination, you can specify how many records you want to fetch per page here. This argument is only used when the `page` argument has been passed in.

When using pagination and you know in advance how many records you want to paginate through, you can pass in that value here. Doing so will prevent Wheels from running a `COUNT` query to get this value. This argument is only used when the `page` argument has been passed in.

Handle to use for the query in pagination. This is useful when you're paginating multiple queries and need to reference them in the @paginationLinks function, for example. This argument is only used when the `page` argument has been passed in.
If you want to cache the query, you can do so by specifying the number of minutes you want to cache the query for here. If you set it to `true`, the default cache time will be used (60 minutes).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set this to `objects` to return an array of objects. Set this to `query` to return a query result set.

When `returnAs` is set to `objects`, you can set this argument to `false` to prevent returning objects fetched from associations specified in the `include` argument. This is useful when you only need to include associations for use in the `WHERE` clause only and want to avoid the performance hit that comes with object creation.
You can set this argument to `false` to prevent running the execution of callbacks for a method call.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Getting only 5 users and ordering them randomly ---> <cfset fiveRandomUsers = model("user").findAll(maxRows=5, order="random")>
<!--- Including an association (which in this case needs to be setup as a `belongsTo` association to `author` on the `article` model first) ---> <cfset articles = model("article").findAll(where="published=1", order="createdAt DESC", include="author")>
<!--- Similar to the above but using the association in the opposite direction (which needs to be setup as a `hasMany` association to `article` on the `author` model) ---> <cfset bobsArticles = model("author").findAll(where="firstName='Bob'", include="articles")>
<!--- Using pagination (getting records 26-50 in this case) and a more complex way to include associations (a song `belongsTo` an album, which in turn `belongsTo` an artist) ---> <cfset songs = model("song").findAll(include="album(artist)", page=2, perPage=25)>
<!--- Using a dynamic finder to get all books released a certain year. Same as calling model("book").findOne(where="releaseYear=#params.year#") ---> <cfset books = model("book").findAllByReleaseYear(params.year)>
<!--- Getting all books of a certain type from a specific year by using a dynamic finder. Same as calling model("book").findAll(where="releaseYear=#params.year# AND type='#params.type#'") ---> <cfset books = model("book").findAllByReleaseYearAndType("#params.year#,#params.type#")>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `comments` method below will call `model("comment").findAll(where="postId=#post.id#")` internally) ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset comments = post.comments()>

d:entry.p: Fetches the requested record by primary key and returns it as an object. Returns `false` if no record is found. You can override this behavior to return a `cfquery` result set instead, similar to what's described in the documentation for @findOne.

code.span: findByKey(key [, select, include, cache, reload, parameterize, returnAs, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Primary key value(s) of the record to fetch. Separate with comma if passing in multiple primary key values. Accepts a string, list, or a numeric value.

Determines how the `SELECT` clause for the query used to return data will look. You can pass in a list of the properties (which map to columns) that you want returned from your table(s). If you don't set this argument at all, Wheels will select all properties from your table(s). If you specify a table name (e.g. `users.email`) or alias a column (e.g. `fn AS firstName`) in the list, then the entire list will be passed through unchanged and used in the `SELECT` clause of the query. By default, all column names in tables `JOIN`ed via the `include` argument will be prepended with the singular version of the included table name.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
If you want to cache the query, you can do so by specifying the number of minutes you want to cache the query for here. If you set it to `true`, the default cache time will be used (60 minutes).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set this to `query` to return as a single-row query result set. Set this to `object` to return as an object.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Getting the author with the primary key value `99` as an object ---> <cfset auth = model("author").findByKey(99)>
<!--- Getting an author based on a form/URL value and then checking if it was found ---> <cfset auth = model("author").findByKey(params.key)> <cfif NOT IsObject(auth)> <cfset flashInsert(message="Author #params.key# was not found")> <cfset redirectTo(back=true)> </cfif>
<!--- If you have a `belongsTo` association setup from `comment` to `post`, you can do a scoped call. (The `post` method below will call `model("post").findByKey(comment.postId)` internally) ---> <cfset comment = model("comment").findByKey(params.commentId)> <cfset post = comment.post()>

d:entry.p: Fetches the first record found based on the `WHERE` and `ORDER BY` clauses. With the default settings (i.e. the `returnAs` argument set to `object`), a model object will be returned if the record is found and the boolean value `false` if not. Instead of using the `where` argument, you can create cleaner code by making use of a concept called dynamic finders.

code.span: findOne([ where, order, select, include, cache, reload, parameterize, returnAs, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
Maps to the `ORDER BY` clause of the query. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Determines how the `SELECT` clause for the query used to return data will look. You can pass in a list of the properties (which map to columns) that you want returned from your table(s). If you don't set this argument at all, Wheels will select all properties from your table(s). If you specify a table name (e.g. `users.email`) or alias a column (e.g. `fn AS firstName`) in the list, then the entire list will be passed through unchanged and used in the `SELECT` clause of the query. By default, all column names in tables `JOIN`ed via the `include` argument will be prepended with the singular version of the included table name.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
If you want to cache the query, you can do so by specifying the number of minutes you want to cache the query for here. If you set it to `true`, the default cache time will be used (60 minutes).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set this to `query` to return as a single-row query result set. Set this to `object` to return as an object.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Getting the most recent order as an object from the database ---> <cfset order = model("order").findOne(order="datePurchased DESC")>
<!--- Using a dynamic finder to get the first person with the last name `Smith`. Same as calling `model("user").findOne(where"lastName='Smith'")` ---> <cfset person = model("user").findOneByLastName("Smith")>
<!--- Getting a specific user using a dynamic finder. Same as calling `model("user").findOne(where"email='someone@somewhere.com' AND password='mypass'")` ---> <cfset user = model("user").findOneByEmailAndPassword("someone@somewhere.com,mypass")>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` association setup from `user` to `profile`, you can do a scoped call. (The `profile` method below will call `model("profile").findOne(where="userId=#user.id#")` internally) ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(params.userId)> <cfset profile = user.profile()>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `findOneComment` method below will call `model("comment").findOne(where="postId=#post.id#")` internally) ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset comment = post.findOneComment(where="text='I Love Wheels!'")>

d:entry.p: Returns the value of a specific key in the Flash (or the entire Flash as a struct if no key is passed in).

tr.td: The key to get the value for.

code.pre:
#flash("message")#

#flash(flashItem)#

d:entry.p: Deletes everything from the Flash.
None.

code.pre: <cfset flashClear()>

d:entry.p: Returns how many keys exist in the Flash.
None.

code.pre: <cfif flashCount() gt 0> do something... </cfif>

d:entry.p: Deletes a specific key from the Flash.

code.pre: <cfset flashDelete(key="errorMessage")>

d:entry.p: Inserts a new key/value into the Flash.
None.

code.pre: <cfset flashInsert(msg="It Worked!")>

d:entry.p: Returns whether or not the Flash is empty.
None.

code.pre: #flash(flashItem)#

d:entry.p: Make the entire Flash or specific key in it stick around for one more request.

tr.td: A key or list of keys to flag for keeping. This argument is also aliased as `keys`.

code.pre:
<!--- Keep the entire Flash for the next request ---> <cfset flashKeep()>
<!--- Keep the "error" key in the Flash for the next request ---> <cfset flashKeep("error")>
<!--- Keep both the "error" and "success" keys in the Flash for the next request ---> <cfset flashKeep("error,success")>

d:entry.p: Checks if a specific key exists in the Flash.

tr.td: The key to check if it exists.

code.pre: #flash("error")#

d:entry.p: Displays a marked-up listing of messages that exists in the Flash.

tr.td: The key (or list of keys) to show the value for. You can also use the `key` argument instead for better readability when accessing a single key.
HTML `class` to set on the `div` element that contains the messages.
Includes the DIV container even if the flash is empty.
Outputs all class attribute values in lower case (except the main one).

code.pre: #flashMessages()# #flashMessages(key="success")# #flashMessages(keys="success,alert")#

d:entry.p: Returns the current setting for the supplied Wheels setting or the current default for the supplied Wheels function argument.

tr.td: Variable name to get setting for.
Function name to get setting for.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the current value for the `tableNamePrefix` Wheels setting ---> <cfset setting = get("tableNamePrefix")>
<!--- Get the default for the `message` argument of the `validatesConfirmationOf` method ---> <cfset setting = get(functionName="validatesConfirmationOf", name="message")>

d:entry.p: Returns the table name prefix set for the table.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get the table name prefix for this user when running a custom query ---> <cffunction name="getDisabledUsers" returntype="query"> <cfset var loc = {}> <cfquery datasource="#get('dataSourceName')#" name="loc.disabledUsers"> SELECT * FROM #this.getTableNamePrefix()#users WHERE disabled = 1 </cfquery> <cfreturn loc.disabledUsers> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Returns `true` if the specified property (or any if none was passed in) has been changed but not yet saved to the database. Will also return `true` if the object is new and no record for it exists in the database.

tr.td: Name of property to check for change.

code.pre:
<!--- Get a member object and change the `email` property on it ---> <cfset member = model("member").findByKey(params.memberId)> <cfset member.email = params.newEmail>
<!--- Check if the `email` property has changed ---> <cfif member.hasChanged("email")> <!--- Do something... ---> </cfif>
<!--- The above can also be done using a dynamic function like this ---> <cfif member.emailHasChanged()> <!--- Do something... ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Returns `true` if the object has any errors. You can also limit to only check a specific property or name for errors.

tr.td: Name of the property to check if there are any errors set on.
Error name to check if there are any errors set with.

code.pre: <!--- Check if the post object has any errors set on it ---> <cfif post.hasErrors()> <!--- Send user to a form to correct the errors... ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Sets up a `hasMany` association between this model and the specified one.

code.span: hasMany(name [, modelName, foreignKey, joinType, dependent, shortcut, through ])

tr.td: Gives the association a name that you refer to when working with the association (in the `include` argument to @findAll, to name one example).
Name of associated model (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions because the model name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Foreign key property name (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions since the foreign key name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Use to set the join type when joining associated tables. Possible values are `inner` (for `INNER JOIN`) and `outer` (for `LEFT OUTER JOIN`).

Defines how to handle dependent models when you delete a record from this model. Set to `delete` to instantiate associated models and call their @delete method, `deleteAll` to delete without instantiating, `nullify` to remove the foreign key, or `false` to do nothing.
Set this argument to create an additional dynamic method that gets the object(s) from the other side of a many-to-many association.

Set this argument if you need to override Wheels conventions when using the `shortcut` argument. Accepts a list of two association names representing the chain from the opposite side of the many-to-many relationship to this model.

code.pre:
<!--- Example1: Specify that instances of this model has many comments. (The table for the associated model, not the current, should have the foreign key set on it.) ---> <cfset hasMany("comments")>
<!--- Example 2: Specify that this model (let's call it `reader` in this case) has many subscriptions and setup a shortcut to the `publication` model. (Useful when dealing with many-to-many relationships.) ---> <cfset hasMany(name="subscriptions", shortcut="publications")>
<!--- Example 3: Automatically delete all associated `comments` whenever this object is deleted ---> <cfset hasMany(name="comments", dependent="deleteAll")>
<!--- Example 4: When not following Wheels naming conventions for associations, it can get complex to define how a `shortcut` works. In this example, we are naming our `shortcut` differently than the actual model's name. ---> <!--- In the models/Customer.cfc `init()` method ---> <cfset hasMany(name="subscriptions", shortcut="magazines", through="publication,subscriptions")>
<!--- In the models/Subscriptions.cfc `init()` method ---> <cfset belongsTo("customer")> <cfset belongsTo("publication")>
<!--- In the models/Publication `init()` method ---> <cfset hasMany("subscriptions")>

d:entry.p: Used as a shortcut to output the proper form elements for an association. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: hasManyCheckBox(objectName, association, keys [, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: Name of the variable containing the parent object to represent with this form field.
Name of the association set in the parent object to represent with this form field.
Primary keys associated with this form field.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre: <!--- Show check boxes for associating authors with the current book ---> <cfloop query="authors"> #hasManyCheckBox( label=authors.fullName, objectName="book", association="bookAuthors", keys="#book.key()#,#authors.id#" )# </cfloop>

d:entry.p: Used as a shortcut to output the proper form elements for an association. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: hasManyRadioButton(objectName, association, property, keys, tagValue [, checkIfBlank, label ])

tr.td: Name of the variable containing the parent object to represent with this form field.
Name of the association set in the parent object to represent with this form field.
Name of the property in the child object to represent with this form field.
Primary keys associated with this form field.
The value of the radio button when `selected`.
Whether or not to check this form field as a default if there is a blank value set for the property.
The label text to use in the form control.

code.pre: <!--- Show radio buttons for associating a default address with the current author ---> <cfloop query="addresses"> #hasManyRadioButton( label=addresses.title, objectName="author", association="authorsDefaultAddresses", keys="#author.key()#,#addresses.id#" )# </cfloop>

d:entry.p: Sets up a `hasOne` association between this model and the specified one.

tr.td: Gives the association a name that you refer to when working with the association (in the `include` argument to @findAll, to name one example).
Name of associated model (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions because the model name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Foreign key property name (usually not needed if you follow Wheels conventions since the foreign key name will be deduced from the `name` argument).
Use to set the join type when joining associated tables. Possible values are `inner` (for `INNER JOIN`) and `outer` (for `LEFT OUTER JOIN`).

Defines how to handle dependent models when you delete a record from this model. Set to `delete` to instantiate associated models and call their @delete method, `deleteAll` to delete without instantiating, `nullify` to remove the foreign key, or `false` to do nothing.

code.pre:
<!--- Specify that instances of this model has one profile. (The table for the associated model, not the current, should have the foreign key set on it.) ---> <cfset hasOne("profile")>
<!--- Same as above but setting the `joinType` to `inner`, which basically means this model should always have a record in the `profiles` table ---> <cfset hasOne(name="profile", joinType="inner")>
<!--- Automatically delete the associated `profile` whenever this object is deleted ---> <cfset hasMany(name="comments", dependent="delete")>

d:entry.p: Returns `true` if the specified property name exists on the model.

code.pre:
<!--- Get an object, set a value and then see if the property exists ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").new()> <cfset employee.firstName = "dude"> <cfset employee.hasProperty("firstName")><!--- returns true --->
<!--- This is also a dynamic method that you could do ---> <cfset employee.hasFirstName()>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a hidden field form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.

code.pre: <!--- Provide an `objectName` and `property` ---> <cfoutput> #hiddenField(objectName="user", property="id")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a hidden field form control based on the supplied `name`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
Value to populate in tag's `value` attribute.

code.pre: <!--- Basic usage usually involves a `name` and `value` ---> <cfoutput> #hiddenFieldTag(name="userId", value=user.id)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Highlights the phrase(s) everywhere in the text if found by wrapping it in a `span` tag.

tr.td: Class to use in `span` tags surrounding highlighted phrase(s).

code.pre: #highlight(text="You searched for: Wheels", phrases="Wheels")# -> You searched for: Wheels

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing one select form control for the hours of the day based on the supplied `name`.

code.span: hourSelectTag(name [, selected, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, twelveHour ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The hour that should be selected initially.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
whether to display the hours in 24 or 12 hour format. 12 hour format has AM/PM drop downs

code.pre:
<!--- This "Tag" version of the function accepts a `name` and `selected` instead of binding to a model object ---> <cfoutput> #hourSelectTag(name="hourOfMeeting", selected=params.hourOfMeeting)# </cfoutput>
<!--- Show 12 hours instead of 24 ---> <cfoutput> #hourSelectTag(name="hourOfMeeting", selected=params.hourOfMeeting, twelveHour=true)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns readable text by capitalizing and converting camel casing to multiple words.

tr.td: a list of strings (space separated) to replace within the output.

code.pre:
<!--- Humanize a string, will result in "Wheels Is A Framework" ---> #humanize("wheelsIsAFramework")#
<!--- Humanize a string, force wheels to replace "Cfml" with "CFML" ---> #humanize("wheelsIsACFMLFramework", "CFML")#

d:entry.p: Converts camelCase strings to lowercase strings with hyphens as word delimiters instead. Example: `myVariable` becomes `my-variable`.

code.pre: <!--- Outputs "my-blog-post" ---> <cfoutput> #hyphenize("myBlogPost")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns an `img` tag. If the image is stored in the local `images` folder, the tag will also set the `width`, `height`, and `alt` attributes for you. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

tr.td: The file name of the image if it's availabe in the local file system (i.e. ColdFusion will be able to access it). Provide the full URL if the image is on a remote server.

code.pre:
<!--- Outputs an `img` tag for `images/logo.png` ---> #imageTag("logo.png")#
<!--- Outputs an `img` tag for `http://cfwheels.org/images/logo.png` ---> #imageTag("http://cfwheels.org/images/logo.png", alt="ColdFusion on Wheels")#
<!--- Outputs an `img` tag with the `class` attribute set ---> #imageTag(source="logo.png", class="logo")#

d:entry.p: Used to output the content for a particular section in a layout.

tr.td: Name of layout section to return content for.
What to display as a default if the section is not defined.

code.pre:
<!--- In your view template, let's say `views/blog/post.cfm ---> <cfset contentFor(head='<meta name="robots" content="noindex,nofollow" />"')> <cfset contentFor(head='<meta name="author" content="wheelsdude@wheelsify.com"')>
<!--- In `views/layout.cfm` ---> <html> <head> <title>My Site</title> #includeContent("head")# </head> <body>
<cfoutput> #includeContent()# </cfoutput>
</body> </html>

d:entry.p: Used as a shortcut to check if the specified IDs are a part of the main form object. This method should only be used for `hasMany` associations.

tr.td: Name of the variable containing the parent object to represent with this form field.
Name of the association set in the parent object to represent with this form field.
Primary keys associated with this form field.

code.pre: <!--- Check to see if the customer is subscribed to the Swimsuit Edition. Note that the order of the `keys` argument should match the order of the `customerid` and `publicationid` columns in the `subscriptions` join table ---> <cfif not includedInObject(objectName="customer", association="subscriptions", keys="#customer.key()#,#swimsuitEdition.id#")> <cfset assignSalesman(customer)> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Includes the contents of another layout file. This is usually used to include a parent layout from within a child layout.

tr.td: Name of the layout file to include.

code.pre:
#includePartial(categories)#
#includeLayout("/layout.cfm")#

d:entry.p: Includes the specified partial file in the view. Similar to using `cfinclude` but with the ability to cache the result and use Wheels-specific file look-up. By default, Wheels will look for the file in the current controller's view folder.
