To include a file relative from the base `views` folder, you can start the path supplied to `name` with a forward slash.

code.span: includePartial(partial [, group, cache, layout, spacer, dataFunction ])

tr.td: The name of the partial file to be used. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Do not include the partial filename's underscore and file extension.
If passing a query result set for the `partial` argument, use this to specify the field to group the query by. A new query will be passed into the partial template for you to iterate over.
Number of minutes to cache the content for.
The layout to wrap the content in. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Pass `false` to not load a layout at all.
HTML or string to place between partials when called using a query.
Name of controller function to load data from.

code.pre:
<cfoutput>#includePartial("login")#</cfoutput> -> If we're in the "admin" controller, Wheels will include the file "views/admin/_login.cfm".
<cfoutput>#includePartial(partial="misc/doc", cache=30)#</cfoutput> -> If we're in the "admin" controller, Wheels will include the file "views/admin/misc/_doc.cfm" and cache it for 30 minutes.
<cfoutput>#includePartial(partial="/shared/button")#</cfoutput> -> Wheels will include the file "views/shared/_button.cfm".

d:entry.p: Runs the specified method within a single database transaction.

tr.td: Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Isolation level to be passed through to the `cftransaction` tag. See your CFML engine's documentation for more details about `cftransaction`'s `isolation` attribute.

code.pre:
<!--- This is the method to be run inside a transaction ---> <cffunction name="tranferFunds" returntype="boolean" output="false"> <cfargument name="personFrom"> <cfargument name="personTo"> <cfargument name="amount"> <cfif arguments.personFrom.withdraw(arguments.amount) and arguments.personTo.deposit(arguments.amount)> <cfreturn true> <cfelse> <cfreturn false> </cfif> </cffunction>
<cfset david = model("Person").findOneByName("David")> <cfset mary = model("Person").findOneByName("Mary")> <cfset invokeWithTransaction(method="transferFunds", personFrom=david, personTo=mary, amount=100)>

d:entry.p: Returns whether the page was called from JavaScript or not.
None.

code.pre: <cfset requestIsAjax = isAjax()>

d:entry.p: Use this method within a model's method to check whether you are currently in a class-level object.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Use the passed in `id` when we're already in an instance ---> <cffunction name="memberIsAdmin"> <cfif isClass()> <cfreturn this.findByKey(arguments.id).admin> <cfelse> <cfreturn this.admin> </cfif> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Returns whether the request was a normal `GET` request or not.
None.

code.pre: <cfset requestIsGet = isGet()>

d:entry.p: Use this method to check whether you are currently in an instance object.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Use the passed in `id` when we're not already in an instance ---> <cffunction name="memberIsAdmin"> <cfif isInstance()> <cfreturn this.admin> <cfelse> <cfreturn this.findByKey(arguments.id).admin> </cfif> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Returns `true` if this object hasn't been saved yet. (In other words, no matching record exists in the database yet.) Returns `false` if a record exists.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Create a new object and then check if it is new (yes, this example is ridiculous. It makes more sense in the context of callbacks for example) ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").new()> <cfif employee.isNew()> <!--- Do something... ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Returns whether the request came from a form `POST` submission or not.
None.

code.pre: <cfset requestIsPost = isPost()>

d:entry.p: Returns whether Wheels is communicating over a secure port.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Redirect non-secure connections to the secure version ---> <cfif not isSecure()> <cfset redirectTo(protocol="https")> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Returns a `script` tag for a JavaScript file (or several) based on the supplied arguments.

tr.td: The name of one or many JavaScript files in the `javascripts` folder, minus the `.js` extension. (Can also be called with the `source` argument.)
Set to `true` to place the output in the `head` area of the HTML page instead of the default behavior, which is to place the output where the function is called from.

code.pre:
<!--- view code ---> <head> <!--- Includes `javascripts/main.js` ---> #javaScriptIncludeTag("main")# <!--- Includes `javascripts/blog.js` and `javascripts/accordion.js` ---> #javaScriptIncludeTag("blog,accordion")# </head>
<body> <!--- Will still appear in the `head` ---> #javaScriptIncludeTag(source="tabs", head=true)# </body>

d:entry.p: Returns the value of the primary key for the object. If you have a single primary key named `id`, then `someObject.key()` is functionally equivalent to `someObject.id`. This method is more useful when you do dynamic programming and don't know the name of the primary key or when you use composite keys (in which case it's convenient to use this method to get a list of both key values returned).
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object and then get the primary key value(s) ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").findByKey(params.key)> <cfset val = employee.key()>

d:entry.p: Creates a link to another page in your application. Pass in the name of a `route` to use your configured routes or a `controller`/`action`/`key` combination. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: linkTo([ text, confirm, route, controller, action, key, params, anchor, onlyPath, host, protocol, port, href ])

tr.td: The text content of the link.
Pass a message here to cause a JavaScript confirmation dialog box to pop up containing the message.
Name of a route that you have configured in `config/routes.cfm`.
Name of the controller to include in the URL.
Name of the action to include in the URL.
Key(s) to include in the URL.
Any additional params to be set in the query string.
Sets an anchor name to be appended to the path.
If `true`, returns only the relative URL (no protocol, host name or port).
Set this to override the current host.
Set this to override the current protocol.
Set this to override the current port number.
Pass a link to an external site here if you want to bypass the Wheels routing system altogether and link to an external URL.

code.pre: #linkTo(text="Log Out", controller="account", action="logout")# -> Log Out #linkTo(text="Log Out", action="logout")# -> Log Out #linkTo(text="View Post", controller="blog", action="post", key=99)# -> View Post #linkTo(text="View Settings", action="settings", params="show=all&sort=asc")# -> View Settings #linkTo(text="Joe's Profile", route="userProfile", userName="joe")# -> Joe's Profile #linkTo(text="ColdFusion Framework", href="http://cfwheels.org/")# -> ColdFusion Framework #linkTo(text="Delete Post", action="delete", key=99, class="delete", id="delete-99")# -> Delete Post

d:entry.p: Creates a `mailto` link tag to the specified email address, which is also used as the name of the link unless name is specified.

tr.td: The email address to link to.
A string to use as the link text ("Joe" or "Support Department", for example).
Pass `true` here to encode the email address, making it harder for bots to harvest it for example.

code.pre: #mailTo(emailAddress="webmaster@yourdomain.com", name="Contact our Webmaster")# -> Contact our Webmaster

d:entry.p: Calculates the maximum value for a given property. Uses the SQL function `MAX`. If no records can be found to perform the calculation on you can use the `ifNull` argument to decide what should be returned.

code.span: maximum(property [, where, include, parameterize, ifNull, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Name of the property to get the highest value for (must be a property of a numeric data type).

This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
The value returned if no records are found. Common usage is to set this to `0` to make sure a numeric value is always returned instead of a blank string.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the amount of the highest salary for all employees ---> <cfset highestSalary = model("employee").maximum("salary")>
<!--- Get the amount of the highest salary for employees in a given department ---> <cfset highestSalary = model("employee").maximum(property="salary", where="departmentId=#params.key#")>
<!--- Make sure a numeric value is always returned, even if no records are found to calculate the maximum for ---> <cfset highestSalary = model("employee").maximum(property="salary", where="salary > #params.minSalary#", ifNull=0)>

d:entry.p: Returns an associated MIME type based on a file extension.

tr.td: The extension to get the MIME type for.
the fallback MIME type to return.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the internally-stored MIME type for `xls` ---> <cfset mimeType = mimeTypes("xls")>
<!--- Get the internally-stored MIME type for a dynamic value. Fall back to a MIME type of `text/plain` if it's not found ---> <cfset mimeType = mimeTypes(extension=params.type, fallback="text/plain")>

d:entry.p: Calculates the minimum value for a given property. Uses the SQL function `MIN`. If no records can be found to perform the calculation on you can use the `ifNull` argument to decide what should be returned.

code.span: minimum(property [, where, include, parameterize, ifNull, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Name of the property to get the lowest value for (must be a property of a numeric data type).

This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
The value returned if no records are found. Common usage is to set this to `0` to make sure a numeric value is always returned instead of a blank string.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the amount of the lowest salary for all employees ---> <cfset lowestSalary = model("employee").minimum("salary")>
<!--- Get the amount of the lowest salary for employees in a given department ---> <cfset lowestSalary = model("employee").minimum(property="salary", where="departmentId=#params.id#")>
<!--- Make sure a numeric amount is always returned, even when there were no records analyzed by the query ---> <cfset lowestSalary = model("employee").minimum(property="salary", where="salary BETWEEN #params.min# AND #params.max#", ifNull=0)>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing one select form control for the minutes of an hour based on the supplied `name`.

code.span: minuteSelectTag(name [, selected, minuteStep, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The minute that should be selected initially.
Pass in `10` to only show minute 10, 20, 30, etc.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre:
<!--- This "Tag" version of the function accepts a `name` and `selected` instead of binding to a model object ---> <cfoutput> #minuteSelectTag(name="minuteOfMeeting", value=params.minuteOfMeeting)# </cfoutput>
<!--- Only show 15-minute intervals ---> <cfoutput> #minuteSelectTag(name="minuteOfMeeting", value=params.minuteOfMeeting, minuteStep=15)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns a reference to the requested model so that class level methods can be called on it.

tr.td: Name of the model to get a reference to.

code.pre: <!--- The `model("author")` part of the code below gets a reference to the model from the application scope, and then the `findByKey` class level method is called on it ---> <cfset authorObject = model("author").findByKey(1)>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a select form control for the months of the year based on the supplied `name`.

code.span: monthSelectTag(name [, selected, monthDisplay, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The month that should be selected initially.
Pass in `names`, `numbers`, or `abbreviations` to control display.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre: <!--- This "Tag" version of the function accepts a `name` and `selected` instead of binding to a model object ---> <cfoutput> #monthSelectTag(name="monthOfBirthday", selected=params.monthOfBirthday)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Allows for nested objects, structs, and arrays to be set from params and other generated data.

code.span: nestedProperties([ association, autoSave, allowDelete, sortProperty, rejectIfBlank ])

tr.td: The association (or list of associations) you want to allow to be set through the params. This argument is also aliased as `associations`.
Whether to save the association(s) when the parent object is saved.
Set `allowDelete` to `true` to tell Wheels to look for the property `_delete` in your model. If present and set to a value that evaluates to `true`, the model will be deleted when saving the parent.
Set `sortProperty` to a property on the object that you would like to sort by. The property should be numeric, should start with 1, and should be consecutive. Only valid with `hasMany` associations.
A list of properties that should not be blank. If any of the properties are blank, any CRUD operations will be rejected.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, allow for `groupEntitlements` to be saved and deleted through the `user` object ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset hasMany("groupEntitlements")> <cfset nestedProperties(association="groupEntitlements", allowDelete=true)> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Creates a new object based on supplied properties and returns it. The object is not saved to the database; it only exists in memory. Property names and values can be passed in either using named arguments or as a struct to the `properties` argument.

tr.td: The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre:
<!--- Create a new author in memory (not saved to the database) ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").new()>
<!--- Create a new author based on properties in a struct ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").new(params.authorStruct)>
<!--- Create a new author by passing in named arguments ---> <cfset newAuthor = model("author").new(firstName="John", lastName="Doe")>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` or `hasMany` association setup from `customer` to `order`, you can do a scoped call. (The `newOrder` method below will call `model("order").new(customerId=aCustomer.id)` internally.) ---> <cfset aCustomer = model("customer").findByKey(params.customerId)> <cfset anOrder = aCustomer.newOrder(shipping=params.shipping)>

d:entry.p: Obfuscates a value. Typically used for hiding primary key values when passed along in the URL.

code.pre: <!--- Obfuscate the primary key value `99` ---> <cfset newValue = obfuscateParam(99)>

d:entry.p: Use this in an individual controller action to define which formats the action will respond with. This can be used to define provides behavior in individual actions or to override a global setting set with @provides in the controller's `init()`.
None.

code.pre:
<!--- In your controller ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset provides("html,xml,json")> </cffunction>
<!--- This action will provide the formats defined in `init()` above ---> <cffunction name="list"> <cfset products = model("product").findAll()> <cfset renderWith(products)> </cffunction>
<!--- This action will only provide the `html` type and will ignore what was defined in the call to `provides()` in the `init()` method above ---> <cffunction name="new"> <cfset onlyProvides("html")> <cfset model("product").new()> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Returns a struct with information about the specificed paginated query. The keys that will be included in the struct are `currentPage`, `totalPages` and `totalRecords`.

tr.td: The handle given to the query to return pagination information for.

code.pre: <cfparam name="params.page" default="1"> <cfset allAuthors = model("author").findAll(page=params.page, perPage=25, order="lastName", handle="authorsData")> <cfset paginationData = pagination("authorsData")>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing links to pages based on a paginated query. Uses @linkTo internally to build the link, so you need to pass in a `route` name or a `controller`/`action`/`key` combination. All other @linkTo arguments can be supplied as well, in which case they are passed through directly to @linkTo. If you have paginated more than one query in the controller, you can use the `handle` argument to reference them. (Don't forget to pass in a `handle` to the @findAll function in your controller first.)

code.span: paginationLinks([ windowSize, alwaysShowAnchors, anchorDivider, linkToCurrentPage, prepend, append, prependToPage, prependOnFirst, prependOnAnchor, appendToPage, appendOnLast, appendOnAnchor, classForCurrent, handle, name, showSinglePage, pageNumberAsParam ])

tr.td: The number of page links to show around the current page.
Whether or not links to the first and last page should always be displayed.
String to place next to the anchors on either side of the list.
Whether or not the current page should be linked to.
String or HTML to be prepended before result.
String or HTML to be appended after result.
String or HTML to be prepended before each page number.
Whether or not to prepend the `prependToPage` string on the first page in the list.
Whether or not to prepend the `prependToPage` string on the anchors.
String or HTML to be appended after each page number.
Whether or not to append the `appendToPage` string on the last page in the list.
Whether or not to append the `appendToPage` string on the anchors.
Class name for the current page number (if `linkToCurrentPage` is `true`, the class name will go on the `a` element. If not, a `span` element will be used).
The handle given to the query that the pagination links should be displayed for.
The name of the param that holds the current page number.
Will show a single page when set to `true`. (The default behavior is to return an empty string when there is only one page in the pagination).
Decides whether to link the page number as a param or as part of a route. (The default behavior is `true`).

code.pre:
• #firstName# #lastName#
    •
#paginationLinks(action="listAuthors")# #paginationLinks(action="listAuthors", windowSize=5)#
    #paginationLinks(action="listAuthors", handle="authQuery", prependToLink="
  • ", appendToLink="
    • ")#
    #paginationLinks(route="paginatedCommentListing", year=2009, month="feb", day=10)#

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a password field form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: passwordField(objectName, property [, association, position, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
<!--- Provide a `label` and the required `objectName` and `property` ---> <cfoutput> #passwordField(label="Password", objectName="user", property="password")# </cfoutput>
<!--- Display fields for passwords provided by the `passwords` association and nested properties ---> <fieldset> <legend>Passwords</legend> <cfloop from="1" to="#ArrayLen(user.passwords)#" index="i"> #passwordField(label="Password ##i#", objectName="user", association="passwords", position=i, property="password")# </cfloop> </fieldset>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a password field form control based on the supplied `name`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: passwordFieldTag(name [, value, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
Value to populate in tag's `value` attribute.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre: <!--- Basic usage usually involves a `label`, `name`, and `value` ---> <cfoutput> #passwordFieldTag(label="Password", name="password", value=params.password)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Returns a list of all installed plugins' names.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Check if the Scaffold plugin is installed ---> <cfif ListFindNoCase("scaffold", pluginNames())> <!--- do something cool ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Returns the plural form of the passed in word. Can also pluralize a word based on a value passed to the `count` argument.

tr.td: Pluralization will occur when this value is not `1`.
Will return `count` prepended to the pluralization when `true` and `count` is not `-1`.

code.pre:
<!--- Pluralize a word, will result in "people" ---> #pluralize("person")#
<!--- Pluralize based on the count passed in ---> Your search returned #pluralize(word="person", count=users.RecordCount)#

d:entry.p: Returns the name of the primary key for this model's table. This is determined through database introspection. If composite primary keys have been used, they will both be returned in a list. This function is also aliased as `primaryKeys()`.

tr.td: If you are accessing a composite primary key, pass the position of a single key to fetch.

code.pre: <!--- Get the name of the primary key of the table mapped to the `employee` model (which is the `employees` table by default) ---> <cfset keyName = model("employee").primaryKey()>

d:entry.p: Alias for @primaryKey. Use this for better readability when you're accessing multiple primary keys.

tr.td: If you are accessing a composite primary key, pass the position of a single key to fetch.

code.pre: <!--- Get a list of the names of the primary keys in the table mapped to the `employee` model (which is the `employees` table by default) ---> <cfset keyNames = model("employee").primaryKeys()>

d:entry.p: Returns a structure of all the properties with their names as keys and the values of the property as values.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get a structure of all the properties for an object ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(1)> <cfset props = user.properties()>

d:entry.p: Use this method to map an object property to either a table column with a different name than the property or to a SQL expression. You only need to use this method when you want to override the default object relational mapping that Wheels performs.

tr.td: The name that you want to use for the column or SQL function result in the CFML code.
The name of the column in the database table to map the property to.
A SQL expression to use to calculate the property value.
A custom label for this property to be referenced in the interface and error messages.
A default value for this property.

code.pre:
<!--- Tell Wheels that when we are referring to `firstName` in the CFML code, it should translate to the `STR_USERS_FNAME` column when interacting with the database instead of the default (which would be the `firstname` column) ---> <cfset property(name="firstName", column="STR_USERS_FNAME")>
<!--- Tell Wheels that when we are referring to `fullName` in the CFML code, it should concatenate the `STR_USERS_FNAME` and `STR_USERS_LNAME` columns ---> <cfset property(name="fullName", sql="STR_USERS_FNAME + ' ' + STR_USERS_LNAME")>
<!--- Tell Wheels that when displaying error messages or labels for form fields, we want to use `First name(s)` as the label for the `STR_USERS_FNAME` column ---> <cfset property(name="firstName", label="First name(s)")>
<!--- Tell Wheels that when creating new objects, we want them to be auto-populated with a `firstName` property of value `Dave` ---> <cfset property(name="firstName", defaultValue="Dave")>

d:entry.p: Returns `true` if the specified property exists on the model and is not a blank string.

code.pre:
<!--- Get an object, set a value and then see if the property exists ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").new()> <cfset employee.firstName = "dude"> <cfreturn employee.propertyIsPresent("firstName")><!--- Returns true --->
<cfset employee.firstName = ""> <cfreturn employee.propertyIsPresent("firstName")><!--- Returns false --->

d:entry.p: Returns a list of property names ordered by their respective column's ordinal position in the database table. Also includes calculated property names that will be generated by the Wheels ORM.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get a list of the property names in use in the user model ---> <cfset propNames = model("user").propertyNames()>

d:entry.p: Use this method to specify which properties cannot be set through mass assignment.

tr.td: Property name (or list of property names) that are not allowed to be altered through mass assignment.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, `firstName` and `lastName` cannot be changed through mass assignment operations like `updateAll()` ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset protectedProperties("firstName,lastName")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Defines formats that the controller will respond with upon request. The format can be requested through a URL variable called `format`, by appending the format name to the end of a URL as an extension (when URL rewriting is enabled), or in the request header.

tr.td: Formats to instruct the controller to provide. Valid values are `html` (the default), `xml`, `json`, `csv`, `pdf`, and `xls`.

code.pre: <!--- In your controller ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset provides("html,xml,json")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a radio button form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: radioButton(objectName, property, tagValue [, association, position, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
The value of the radio button when `selected`.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
Gender #radioButton(objectName="user", property="gender", tagValue="m", label="Male")#
#radioButton(objectName="user", property="gender", tagValue="f", label="Female")#

#committee.members[i].fullName#:

#radioButton(objectName="committee", association="members", position=i, property="gender", tagValue="m", label="Male")#
#radioButton(objectName="committee", association="members", position=i, property="gender", tagValue="f", label="Female")#

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a radio button form control based on the supplied `name`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: radioButtonTag(name, value [, checked, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
Value to populate in tag's `value` attribute.
Whether or not to check the radio button by default.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre:
Gender #radioButtonTag(name="gender", value="m", label="Male", checked=true)#
#radioButtonTag(name="gender", value="f", label="Female")#

d:entry.p: Redirects the browser to the supplied `controller`/`action`/`key`, `route` or back to the referring page. Internally, this function uses the @URLFor function to build the link and the `cflocation` tag to perform the redirect.

code.span: redirectTo([ back, addToken, statusCode, route, controller, action, key, params, anchor, onlyPath, host, protocol, port, delay ])

tr.td: Set to `true` to redirect back to the referring page.
See documentation for your CFML engine's implementation of `cflocation`.
See documentation for your CFML engine's implementation of `cflocation`.
Name of a route that you have configured in `config/routes.cfm`.
Name of the controller to include in the URL.
Name of the action to include in the URL.
Key(s) to include in the URL.
Any additional params to be set in the query string.
Sets an anchor name to be appended to the path.
If `true`, returns only the relative URL (no protocol, host name or port).
Set this to override the current host.
Set this to override the current protocol.
Set this to override the current port number.
Set to `true` to delay the redirection until after the rest of your action code has executed.

code.pre:
<!--- Redirect to an action after successfully saving a user ---> <cfif user.save()> <cfset redirectTo(action="saveSuccessful")> </cfif>
<!--- Redirect to a specific page on a secure server ---> <cfset redirectTo(controller="checkout", action="start", params="type=express", protocol="https")>
<!--- Redirect to a route specified in `config/routes.cfm` and pass in the screen name that the route takes ---> <cfset redirectTo(route="profile", screenName="Joe")>
<!--- Redirect back to the page the user came from ---> <cfset redirectTo(back=true)>

d:entry.p: Reloads the property values of this object from the database.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, call a method on it that could potentially change values, and then reload the values from the database ---> <cfset employee = model("employee").findByKey(params.key)> <cfset employee.someCallThatChangesValuesInTheDatabase()> <cfset employee.reload()>

d:entry.p: Instructs the controller to render an empty string when it's finished processing the action. This is very similar to calling `cfabort` with the advantage that any after filters you have set on the action will still be run.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Render a blank white page to the client ---> <cfset renderNothing()>

d:entry.p: Instructs the controller which view template and layout to render when it's finished processing the action. Note that when passing values for `controller` and/or `action`, this function does not load the actual action but rather just loads the corresponding view template.

code.span: renderPage([ controller, action, template, layout, cache, returnAs, hideDebugInformation ])

tr.td: Controller to include the view page for.
Action to include the view page for.
A specific template to render. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder.
The layout to wrap the content in. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Pass `false` to not load a layout at all.
Number of minutes to cache the content for.
Set to `string` to return the result instead of automatically sending it to the client.
Set to `true` to hide the debug information at the end of the output. This is useful when you're testing XML output in an environment where the global setting for `showDebugInformation` is `true`.

code.pre:
<!--- Render a view page for a different action within the same controller ---> <cfset renderPage(action="edit")>
<!--- Render a view page for a different action within a different controller ---> <cfset renderPage(controller="blog", action="new")>
<!--- Another way to render the blog/new template from within a different controller ---> <cfset renderPage(template="/blog/new")>
<!--- Render the view page for the current action but without a layout and cache it for 60 minutes ---> <cfset renderPage(layout=false, cache=60)>
<!--- Load a layout from a different folder within `views` ---> <cfset renderPage(layout="/layouts/blog")>
<!--- Don't render the view immediately but rather return and store in a variable for further processing ---> <cfset myView = renderPage(returnAs="string")>

d:entry.p: Instructs the controller to render a partial when it's finished processing the action.

tr.td: The name of the partial file to be used. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Do not include the partial filename's underscore and file extension.
Number of minutes to cache the content for.
The layout to wrap the content in. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Pass `false` to not load a layout at all.
Set to `string` to return the result instead of automatically sending it to the client.
Name of a controller function to load data from.

code.pre:
<!--- Render the partial `_comment.cfm` located in the current controller's view folder ---> <cfset renderPartial("comment")>
<!--- Render the partial at `views/shared/_comment.cfm` ---> <cfset renderPartial("/shared/comment")>

d:entry.p: Instructs the controller to render specified text when it's finished processing the action.

code.pre:
<!--- Render just the text "Done!" to the client ---> <cfset renderText("Done!")>
<!--- Render serialized product data to the client ---> <cfset products = model("product").findAll()> <cfset renderText(SerializeJson(products))>

d:entry.p: Instructs the controller to render the data passed in to the format that is requested. If the format requested is `json` or `xml`, Wheels will transform the data into that format automatically. For other formats (or to override the automatic formatting), you can also create a view template in this format: `nameofaction.xml.cfm`, `nameofaction.json.cfm`, `nameofaction.pdf.cfm`, etc.

code.span: renderWith(data [, controller, action, template, layout, cache, returnAs, hideDebugInformation ])

tr.td: Controller to include the view page for.
Action to include the view page for.
A specific template to render. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder.
The layout to wrap the content in. Prefix with a leading slash `/` if you need to build a path from the root `views` folder. Pass `false` to not load a layout at all.
Number of minutes to cache the content for.
Set to `string` to return the result instead of automatically sending it to the client.
Set to `true` to hide the debug information at the end of the output. This is useful when you're testing XML output in an environment where the global setting for `showDebugInformation` is `true`.

code.pre:
<!--- In your controller ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset provides("html,xml,json")> </cffunction>
<!--- This action will provide the formats defined in `init()` above ---> <cffunction name="list"> <cfset products = model("product").findAll()> <cfset renderWith(products)> </cffunction>
<!--- This action will only provide the `html` type and will ignore what was defined in the call to `provides()` in the `init()` method above ---> <cffunction name="new"> <cfset onlyProvides("html")> <cfset model("product").new()> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Resets a cycle so that it starts from the first list value the next time it is called.

tr.td: The name of the cycle to reset.

code.pre:
• #categories.categoryName#
    •

d:entry.p: Returns content that Wheels will send to the client in response to the request.
None.

code.pre:
<!--- In a controller ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset filters(type="after", through="translateResponse")> </cffunction>
<!--- After filter translates response and sets it ---> <cffunction name="translateResponse"> <cfset var wheelsResponse = response()> <cfset var translatedResponse = someTranslationMethod(wheelsResponse)> <cfset setResponse(translatedResponse)> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Saves the object if it passes validation and callbacks. Returns `true` if the object was saved successfully to the database, `false` if not.

code.span: save([ parameterize, reload, validate, transaction, callbacks ])

tr.td: Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set to `true` to reload the object from the database once an insert/update has completed.
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre:
<!--- Save the user object to the database (will automatically do an `INSERT` or `UPDATE` statement depending on if the record is new or already exists ---> <cfset user.save()>
<!--- Save the user object directly in an if statement without using `cfqueryparam` and take appropriate action based on the result ---> <cfif user.save(parameterize=false)> <cfset flashInsert(notice="The user was saved!")> <cfset redirectTo(action="edit")> <cfelse> <cfset flashInsert(alert="Error, please correct!")> <cfset renderPage(action="edit")> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing one select form control for the seconds of a minute based on the supplied `name`.

code.span: secondSelectTag(name [, selected, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The second that should be selected initially.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre: <!--- This "Tag" version of the function accepts a `name` and `selected` instead of binding to a model object ---> <cfoutput> #secondSelectTag(name="secondsToLaunch", selected=params.secondsToLaunch)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a `select` form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: select(objectName, property, options [, association, position, includeBlank, valueField, textField, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
A collection to populate the select form control with. Can be a query recordset or an array of objects.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The column or property to use for the value of each list element. Used only when a query or array of objects has been supplied in the `options` argument.
The column or property to use for the value of each list element that the end user will see. Used only when a query or array of objects has been supplied in the `options` argument.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
#select(objectName="book", property="authorId", options=authors)#

 #select(label="Order ##shipments.orders[i].orderNum#", objectName="shipment", association="orders", position=i, property="statusId", options=statuses)#

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a select form control based on the supplied `name` and `options`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: selectTag(name, options [, selected, includeBlank, multiple, valueField, textField, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
A collection to populate the select form control with. Can be a query recordset or an array of objects.
Value of option that should be selected by default.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
Whether to allow multiple selection of options in the select form control.
The column or property to use for the value of each list element. Used only when a query or array of objects has been supplied in the `options` argument.
The column or property to use for the value of each list element that the end user will see. Used only when a query or array of objects has been supplied in the `options` argument.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre:
<!--- Controller code ---> <cfset cities = model("city").findAll()>
<!--- View code ---> <cfoutput> #selectTag(name="cityId", options=cities)# </cfoutput>
<!--- Do this when Wheels isn't grabbing the correct values for the `option`s' values and display texts ---> <cfoutput> #selectTag(name="cityId", options=cities, valueField="id", textField="name")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Sends an email using a template and an optional layout to wrap it in. Besides the Wheels-specific arguments documented here, you can also pass in any argument that is accepted by the `cfmail` tag as well as your own arguments to be used by the view.

code.span: sendEmail(from, to, subject [, template, layout, file, detectMultipart ])

tr.td: The path to the email template or two paths if you want to send a multipart email. if the `detectMultipart` argument is `false`, the template for the text version should be the first one in the list. This argument is also aliased as `templates`.
List of email addresses to send the email to.
The subject line of the email.
Layout(s) to wrap the email template in. This argument is also aliased as `layouts`.
A list of the names of the files to attach to the email. This will reference files stored in the `files` folder (or a path relative to it). This argument is also aliased as `files`.
When set to `true` and multiple values are provided for the `template` argument, Wheels will detect which of the templates is text and which one is HTML (by counting the `<` characters).

code.pre: <!--- Get a member and send a welcome email, passing in a few custom variables to the template ---> <cfset newMember = model("member").findByKey(params.member.id)> <cfset sendEmail( to=newMember.email, template="myemailtemplate", subject="Thank You for Becoming a Member", recipientName=newMember.name, startDate=newMember.startDate )>

d:entry.p: Sends a file to the user (from the `files` folder or a path relative to it by default).

code.span: sendFile(file [, name, type, disposition, directory, deleteFile ])

tr.td: The file to send to the user.
The file name to show in the browser download dialog box.
The HTTP content type to deliver the file as.
Set to `inline` to have the browser handle the opening of the file (possibly inline in the browser) or set to `attachment` to force a download dialog box.
Directory outside of the webroot where the file exists. Must be a full path.
Pass in `true` to delete the file on the server after sending it.

code.pre:
<!--- Send a PDF file to the user ---> <cfset sendFile(file="wheels_tutorial_20081028_J657D6HX.pdf")>
<!--- Send the same file but give the user a different name in the browser dialog window ---> <cfset sendFile(file="wheels_tutorial_20081028_J657D6HX.pdf", name="Tutorial.pdf")>
<!--- Send a file that is located outside of the web root ---> <cfset sendFile(file="../../tutorials/wheels_tutorial_20081028_J657D6HX.pdf")>

d:entry.p: Use to configure a global setting or set a default for a function.
None.
Use this function if you need a more low level way of setting the entire filter chain for a controller.

tr.td: An array of structs, each of which represent an `argumentCollection` that get passed to the `filters` function. This should represent the entire filter chain that you want to use for this controller.

code.pre:
<!--- Set filter chain directly in an array --->
<cfset setFilterChain([
	{through="restrictAccess"},
	{through="isLoggedIn,checkIPAddress", except="home,login"},
	{type="after", through="logConversion", only="thankYou"}
])>

d:entry.p: Allows you to set a pagination handle for a custom query so you can perform pagination on it in your view with `paginationLinks()`.

tr.td: Total count of records that should be represented by the paginated links.
Page number that should be represented by the data being fetched and the paginated links.
Number of records that should be represented on each page of data.
Name of handle to reference in @paginationLinks.

code.pre:
SELECT * FROM users
  • #allUsers.firstName# #allUsers.lastName#
    •
#paginationLinks(handle="myCustomQueryHandle")#
  • #allUsers.firstName# #allUsers.lastName#
    •
#paginationLinks(handle="myCustomQueryHandle")# SELECT COUNT(*) AS theCount FROM users SELECT * FROM users LIMIT #arguments.page# OFFSET #arguments.perPage#
  • #allUsers.firstName# #allUsers.lastName#
    •
#paginationLinks(handle="myCustomQueryHandle")#
  • #allUsers.firstName# #allUsers.lastName#
    •
#paginationLinks(handle="myCustomQueryHandle")#

d:entry.p: Allows you to pass in the name(s) of the property(s) that should be used as the primary key(s). Pass as a list if defining a composite primary key. Also aliased as `setPrimaryKeys()`.

tr.td: Property (or list of properties) to set as the primary key.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, define the primary key as a column called `userID` ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset setPrimaryKey("userID")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Alias for @setPrimaryKey. Use this for better readability when you're setting multiple properties as the primary key.

tr.td: Property (or list of properties) to set as the primary key.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/Subscription.cfc`, define the primary key as composite of the columns `customerId` and `publicationId` ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset setPrimaryKeys("customerId,publicationId")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Allows you to set all the properties of an object at once by passing in a structure with keys matching the property names.

tr.td: The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).

code.pre: <!--- Update the properties of the object with the params struct containing the values of a form post ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(1)> <cfset user.setProperties(params.user)>

d:entry.p: Sets content that Wheels will send to the client in response to the request.

tr.td: The content to set as the response.

code.pre:
<!--- In a controller ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset filters(type="after", through="translateResponse")> </cffunction>
<!--- After filter translates response and sets it ---> <cffunction name="translateResponse"> <cfset var wheelsResponse = response()> <cfset var translatedResponse = someTranslationFunction(wheelsResponse)> <cfset setResponse(translatedResponse)> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Sets a prefix to prepend to the table name when this model runs SQL queries.

tr.td: A prefix to prepend to the table name.

code.pre: <!--- In `models/User.cfc`, add a prefix to the default table name of `tbl` ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset setTableNamePrefix("tbl")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Use this function if you need a more low level way of setting the entire verification chain for a controller.

tr.td: An array of structs, each of which represent an `argumentCollection` that get passed to the `verifies` function. This should represent the entire verification chain that you want to use for this controller.

code.pre:
<!--- Set verification chain directly in an array --->
<cfset setVerificationChain([
	{only="handleForm", post=true},
	{only="edit", get=true, params="userId", paramsTypes="integer"},
	{only="edit", get=true, params="userId", paramsTypes="integer", handler="index", error="Invalid userId"}
])>

d:entry.p: Replaces single newline characters with HTML break tags and double newline characters with HTML paragraph tags (properly closed to comply with XHTML standards).

tr.td: Set to `true` to wrap the result in a paragraph.

code.pre:
#simpleFormat(post.comments)# I love this post! Here's why: * Short * Succinct * Awesome #simpleFormat(comment)# ->

I love this post!

Here's why:
* Short
* Succinct
* Awesome

d:entry.p: Returns the singular form of the passed in word.

code.pre: <!--- Singularize a word, will result in "language" ---> #singularize("languages")#

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing the opening form tag. The form's action will be built according to the same rules as `URLFor`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: startFormTag([ method, multipart, spamProtection, route, controller, action, key, params, anchor, onlyPath, host, protocol, port ])

tr.td: The type of method to use in the form tag. `get` and `post` are the options.
Set to `true` if the form should be able to upload files.
Set to `true` to protect the form against spammers (done with JavaScript).
Name of a route that you have configured in `config/routes.cfm`.
Name of the controller to include in the URL.
Name of the action to include in the URL.
Key(s) to include in the URL.
Any additional params to be set in the query string.
Sets an anchor name to be appended to the path.
If `true`, returns only the relative URL (no protocol, host name or port).
Set this to override the current host.
Set this to override the current protocol.
Set this to override the current port number.

code.pre: <!--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #startFormTag(action="create", spamProtection=true)# <!--- your form controls ---> #endFormTag()# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Removes all links from an HTML string, leaving just the link text.

code.pre: #stripLinks("Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion.")# -> Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion.

d:entry.p: Returns a `link` tag for a stylesheet (or several) based on the supplied arguments.

tr.td: The name of one or many CSS files in the `stylesheets` folder, minus the `.css` extension. (Can also be called with the `source` argument.)
Set to `true` to place the output in the `head` area of the HTML page instead of the default behavior, which is to place the output where the function is called from.

code.pre:
<!--- view code ---> <head> <!--- Includes `stylesheets/styles.css` ---> #styleSheetLinkTag("styles")# <!--- Includes `stylesheets/blog.css` and `stylesheets/comments.css` ---> #styleSheetLinkTag("blog,comments")# <!--- Includes printer style sheet ---> #styleSheetLinkTag(source="print", media="print")# </head>
<body> <!--- This will still appear in the `head` ---> #styleSheetLinkTag(source="tabs", head=true)# </body>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a submit button `form` control. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

tr.td: Message to display in the button form control.
File name of the image file to use in the button form control.
Whether or not to disable the button upon clicking. (prevents double-clicking.)

code.pre: !--- view code ---> <cfoutput> #startFormTag(action="something")# <!--- form controls go here ---> #submitTag()# #endFormTag()# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Calculates the sum of values for a given property. Uses the SQL function `SUM`. If no records can be found to perform the calculation on you can use the `ifNull` argument to decide what should be returned.

code.span: sum(property [, where, include, distinct, parameterize, ifNull, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Name of the property to get the sum for (must be a property of a numeric data type).

This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
When `true`, `SUM` returns the sum of unique values only.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
The value returned if no records are found. Common usage is to set this to `0` to make sure a numeric value is always returned instead of a blank string.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Get the sum of all salaries ---> <cfset allSalaries = model("employee").sum("salary")>
<!--- Get the sum of all salaries for employees in a given country ---> <cfset allAustralianSalaries = model("employee").sum(property="salary", include="country", where="countryname='Australia'")>
<!--- Make sure a numeric value is always returned, even if there are no records analyzed by the query ---> <cfset salarySum = model("employee").sum(property="salary", where="salary BETWEEN #params.min# AND #params.max#", ifNull=0)>

d:entry.p: Use this method to tell Wheels what database table to connect to for this model. You only need to use this method when your table naming does not follow the standard Wheels convention of a singular object name mapping to a plural table name.

tr.td: Name of the table to map this model to.

code.pre: <!--- In models/User.cfc ---> <cffunction name="init"> <!--- Tell Wheels to use the `tbl_USERS` table in the database for the `user` model instead of the default (which would be `users`) ---> <cfset table("tbl_USERS")> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Returns the name of the database table that this model is mapped to.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Check what table the user model uses ---> <cfset whatAmIMappedTo = model("user").tableName()>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a text area field form control based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`. Note: Pass any additional arguments like `class`, `rel`, and `id`, and the generated tag will also include those values as HTML attributes.

code.span: textArea(objectName, property [, association, position, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

The position used when referencing a `hasMany` relationship in the `association` argument. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nestings, simply pass in a list of positions, and Wheels will figure it out.
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.

code.pre:
<!--- Provide `label` and required `objectName` and `property` ---> <cfoutput> #textArea(label="Overview", objectName="article", property="overview")# </cfoutput>
<!--- Display fields for photos provided by the `screenshots` association and nested properties ---> <fieldset> <legend>Screenshots</legend> <cfloop from="1" to="#ArrayLen(site.screenshots)#" index="i"> #fileField(label="File ##i#", objectName="site", association="screenshots", position=i, property="file")# #textArea(label="Caption ##i#", objectName="site", association="screenshots", position=i, property="caption")# </cfloop> </fieldset>

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing three select form controls for hour, minute, and second based on the supplied `objectName` and `property`.

code.span: timeSelect([ objectName, property, association, position, order, separator, minuteStep, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel, errorElement, errorClass, combine, twelveHour ])

tr.td: The variable name of the object to build the form control for.
The name of the property to use in the form control.

The name of the association that the property is located on. Used for building nested forms that work with nested properties. If you are building a form with deep nesting, simply pass in a list to the nested object, and Wheels will figure it out.

Use to change the order of or exclude time select tags.
Use to change the character that is displayed between the time select tags.
Pass in `10` to only show minute 10, 20, 30, etc.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control. The label will be applied to all `select` tags, but you can pass in a list to cutomize each one individually.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
HTML tag to wrap the form control with when the object contains errors.
The class name of the HTML tag that wraps the form control when there are errors.
Set to `false` to not combine the select parts into a single `DateTime` object.
whether to display the hours in 24 or 12 hour format. 12 hour format has AM/PM drop downs

<!--- View code ---> <cfoutput> #timeSelect(objectName="business", property="openUntil")# </cfoutput>

<!--- Only show 15-minute intervals ---> <cfoutput> #timeSelect(objectName="appointment", property="dateTimeStart", minuteStep=15)# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Capitalizes all words in the text to create a nicer looking title.
