code.pre: #titleize("Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion")# -> Wheels Is A Framework For ColdFusion

d:entry.p: Assigns to the property specified the opposite of the property's current boolean value. Throws an error if the property cannot be converted to a boolean value. Returns this object if save called internally is `false`.

tr.td: Argument to decide whether save the property after it has been toggled. Defaults to true.

code.pre: <!--- Get an object, and toggle a boolean property ---> <cfset user = model("user").findByKey(58)> <cfset isSuccess = user.toggle("isActive")><!--- returns whether the object was saved properly ---> <!--- You can also use a dynamic helper for this ---> <cfset isSuccess = user.toggleIsActive()>

d:entry.p: Returns an XHTML-compliant string.

code.pre: <!--- Outputs `productId=5&categoryId=12&returningCustomer=1` ---> <cfoutput> #toXHTML("productId=5&categoryId=12&returningCustomer=1")# </cfoutput>

d:entry.p: Truncates text to the specified length and replaces the last characters with the specified truncate string (which defaults to "...").

tr.td: Length to truncate the text to.
String to replace the last characters with.

code.pre:
#truncate(text="Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion", length=20)# -> Wheels is a frame...
#truncate(text="Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion", truncateString=" (more)")# -> Wheels is a framework f (more)

d:entry.p: Updates the object with the supplied properties and saves it to the database. Returns `true` if the object was saved successfully to the database and `false` otherwise.

code.span: update([ properties, parameterize, reload, validate, transaction, callbacks ])

tr.td: The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre:
<!--- Get a post object and then update its title in the database ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(33)> <cfset post.update(title="New version of Wheels just released")>
<!--- Get a post object and then update its title and other properties based on what is pased in from the URL/form ---> <cfset post = model("post").findByKey(params.key)> <cfset post.update(title="New version of Wheels just released", properties=params.post)>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` association setup from `author` to `bio`, you can do a scoped call. (The `setBio` method below will call `bio.update(authorId=anAuthor.id)` internally.) ---> <cfset author = model("author").findByKey(params.authorId)> <cfset bio = model("bio").findByKey(params.bioId)> <cfset author.setBio(bio)>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `owner` to `car`, you can do a scoped call. (The `addCar` method below will call `car.update(ownerId=anOwner.id)` internally.) ---> <cfset anOwner = model("owner").findByKey(params.ownerId)> <cfset aCar = model("car").findByKey(params.carId)> <cfset anOwner.addCar(aCar)>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `removeComment` method below will call `comment.update(postId="")` internally.) ---> <cfset aPost = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset aComment = model("comment").findByKey(params.commentId)> <cfset aPost.removeComment(aComment)>

d:entry.p: Updates all properties for the records that match the `where` argument. Property names and values can be passed in either using named arguments or as a struct to the `properties` argument. By default, objects will not be instantiated and therefore callbacks and validations are not invoked. You can change this behavior by passing in `instantiate=true`. This method returns the number of records that were updated.

code.span: updateAll([ where, include, properties, reload, parameterize, instantiate, validate, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.

Associations that should be included in the query using `INNER` or `LEFT OUTER` joins (which join type that is used depends on how the association has been set up in your model). If all included associations are set on the current model, you can specify them in a list (e.g. `department,addresses,emails`). You can build more complex `include` strings by using parentheses when the association is set on an included model, like `album(artist(genre))`, for example. These complex `include` strings only work when `returnAs` is set to `query` though.
The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Whether or not to instantiate the object(s) first. When objects are not instantiated, any callbacks and validations set on them will be skipped.
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Update the `published` and `publishedAt` properties for all records that have `published=0` ---> <cfset recordsUpdated = model("post").updateAll(published=1, publishedAt=Now(), where="published=0")>
<!--- If you have a `hasMany` association setup from `post` to `comment`, you can do a scoped call. (The `removeAllComments` method below will call `model("comment").updateAll(postid="", where="postId=#post.id#")` internally.) ---> <cfset aPost = model("post").findByKey(params.postId)> <cfset removedSuccessfully = aPost.removeAllComments()>

d:entry.p: Finds the object with the supplied key and saves it (if validation permits it) with the supplied properties and/or named arguments. Property names and values can be passed in either using named arguments or as a struct to the `properties` argument. Returns `true` if the object was found and updated successfully, `false` otherwise.

code.span: updateByKey(key [, properties, reload, validate, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: Primary key value(s) of the record to fetch. Separate with comma if passing in multiple primary key values. Accepts a string, list, or a numeric value.
The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Updates the object with `33` as the primary key value with values passed in through the URL/form ---> <cfset result = model("post").updateByKey(33, params.post)>
<!--- Updates the object with `33` as the primary key using named arguments ---> <cfset result = model("post").updateByKey(key=33, title="New version of Wheels just released", published=1)>

d:entry.p: Gets an object based on the arguments used and updates it with the supplied properties. Returns `true` if an object was found and updated successfully, `false` otherwise.

code.span: updateOne([ where, order, properties, reload, validate, transaction, callbacks, includeSoftDeletes ])

tr.td: This argument maps to the `WHERE` clause of the query. The following operators are supported: `=`, `!=`, `<>`, `<`, `<=`, `>`, `>=`, `LIKE`, `NOT LIKE`, `IN`, `NOT IN`, `IS NULL`, `IS NOT NULL`, `AND`, and `OR`. (Note that the key words need to be written in upper case.) You can also use parentheses to group statements. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
Maps to the `ORDER BY` clause of the query. You do not need to specify the table name(s); Wheels will do that for you.
The properties you want to set on the object (can also be passed in as named arguments).

Set to `true` to force Wheels to query the database even though an identical query may have been run in the same request. (The default in Wheels is to get the second query from the request-level cache.)
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.
You can set this argument to `true` to include soft-deleted records in the results.

code.pre:
<!--- Sets the `new` property to `1` on the most recently released product ---> <cfset result = model("product").updateOne(order="releaseDate DESC", new=1)>
<!--- If you have a `hasOne` association setup from `user` to `profile`, you can do a scoped call. (The `removeProfile` method below will call `model("profile").updateOne(where="userId=#aUser.id#", userId="")` internally.) ---> <cfset aUser = model("user").findByKey(params.userId)> <cfset aUser.removeProfile()>

d:entry.p: Updates all the properties from the `properties` argument or other named arguments. If the object is invalid, the save will fail and `false` will be returned.

code.span: updateProperties([ properties, parameterize, validate, transaction, callbacks ])

tr.td: Struct containing key/value pairs with properties and associated values that need to be updated globally.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set to `false` to skip validations for this operation.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre: <!--- Sets the `new` property to `1` through `updateProperties()` ---> <cfset product = model("product").findByKey(56)> <cfset product.updateProperties(new=1)>

d:entry.p: Updates a single property and saves the record without going through the normal validation procedure. This is especially useful for boolean flags on existing records.

tr.td: Name of the property to update the value for globally.
Value to set on the given property globally.
Set to `true` to use `cfqueryparam` on all columns, or pass in a list of property names to use `cfqueryparam` on those only.
Set this to `commit` to update the database when the save has completed, `rollback` to run all the database queries but not commit them, or `none` to skip transaction handling altogether.
Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre: <!--- Sets the `new` property to `1` through updateProperty() ---> <cfset product = model("product").findByKey(56)> <cfset product.updateProperty("new", 1)>

d:entry.p: Creates an internal URL based on supplied arguments.

code.span: URLFor([ route, controller, action, key, params, anchor, onlyPath, host, protocol, port ])

tr.td: Name of a route that you have configured in `config/routes.cfm`.
Name of the controller to include in the URL.
Name of the action to include in the URL.
Key(s) to include in the URL.
Any additional params to be set in the query string.
Sets an anchor name to be appended to the path.
If `true`, returns only the relative URL (no protocol, host name or port).
Set this to override the current host.
Set this to override the current protocol.
Set this to override the current port number.

code.pre:
<!--- Create the URL for the `logOut` action on the `account` controller, typically resulting in `/account/log-out` ---> #URLFor(controller="account", action="logOut")#
<!--- Create a URL with an anchor set on it ---> #URLFor(action="comments", anchor="comment10")#
<!--- Create a URL based on a route called `products`, which expects params for `categorySlug` and `productSlug` ---> #URLFor(route="product", categorySlug="accessories", productSlug="battery-charger")#

d:entry.p: Used within a controller's `init()` method to specify controller- or action-specific layouts.

tr.td: Name of the layout template or method name you want to use
Name of the layout template you want to use for AJAX requests
List of actions that SHOULD NOT get the layout
List of action that SHOULD ONLY get the layout
When specifying conditions or a method, pass `true` to use the default `layout.cfm` if none of the conditions are met

code.pre:
<!--- Example 1: We want this layout to be used as the default throughout the entire controller, except for the myajax action ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset usesLayout(template="myLayout", except="myajax")> </cffunction>
<!--- Example 2: Use a custom layout for these actions but use the default layout.cfm for the rest ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset usesLayout(template="myLayout", only="termsOfService,shippingPolicy")> </cffunction>
<!--- Example 3: Define a custom method to decide which layout to display ---> <cffunction name="init"> <cfset usesLayout("setLayout")> </cffunction>
<cffunction name="setLayout"> <!--- Use holiday theme for the month of December ---> <cfif Month(Now()) eq 12> <cfreturn "holiday"> <!--- Otherwise, use default layout by returning `true` ---> <cfelse> <cfreturn true> </cfif> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Runs the validation on the object and returns `true` if it passes it. Wheels will run the validation process automatically whenever an object is saved to the database, but sometimes it's useful to be able to run this method to see if the object is valid without saving it to the database.

tr.td: Set to `false` to disable callbacks for this operation.

code.pre: <!--- Check if a user is valid before proceeding with execution ---> <cfset user = model("user").new(params.user)> <cfif user.valid()> <!--- Do something here ---> </cfif>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called to validate objects before they are saved.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names to call. (Can also be called with the `method` argument.)
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<cffunction name="init"> <!--- Register the `checkPhoneNumber` method below to be called to validate objects before they are saved ---> <cfset validate("checkPhoneNumber")> </cffunction>
<cffunction name="checkPhoneNumber"> <!--- Make sure area code is `614` ---> <cfreturn Left(this.phoneNumber, 3) is "614"> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called to validate new objects before they are inserted.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names to call. (Can also be called with the `method` argument.)
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<cffunction name="init"> <!--- Register the `checkPhoneNumber` method below to be called to validate new objects before they are inserted ---> <cfset validateOnCreate("checkPhoneNumber")> </cffunction>
<cffunction name="checkPhoneNumber"> <!--- Make sure area code is `614` ---> <cfreturn Left(this.phoneNumber, 3) is "614"> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Registers method(s) that should be called to validate existing objects before they are updated.

tr.td: Method name or list of method names to call. (Can also be called with the `method` argument.)
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<cffunction name="init"> <!--- Register the `check` method below to be called to validate existing objects before they are updated ---> <cfset validateOnUpdate("checkPhoneNumber")> </cffunction>
<cffunction name="checkPhoneNumber"> <!--- Make sure area code is `614` ---> <cfreturn Left(this.phoneNumber, 3) is "614"> </cffunction>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property also has an identical confirmation value. (This is common when having a user type in their email address a second time to confirm, confirming a password by typing it a second time, etc.) The confirmation value only exists temporarily and never gets saved to the database. By convention, the confirmation property has to be named the same as the property with "Confirmation" appended at the end. Using the password example, to confirm our `password` property, we would create a property called `passwordConfirmation`.

code.span: validatesConfirmationOf([ properties, message, when, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre: <!--- Make sure that the user has to confirm their password correctly the first time they register (usually done by typing it again in a second form field) ---> <cfset validatesConfirmationOf(property="password", when="onCreate", message="Your password and its confirmation do not match. Please try again.")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property does not exist in the supplied list.

code.span: validatesExclusionOf(list [, properties, message, when, allowBlank, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Single value or list of values that should not be allowed.
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre: <!--- Do not allow "PHP" or "Fortran" to be saved to the database as a cool language ---> <cfset validatesExclusionOf(property="coolLanguage", list="php,fortran", message="Haha, you can not be serious. Try again, please.")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property is formatted correctly by matching it against a regular expression using the `regEx` argument and/or against a built-in CFML validation type using the `type` argument (`creditcard`, `date`, `email`, etc.).

code.span: validatesFormatOf([ properties, regEx, type, message, when, allowBlank, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).

One of the following types to verify against: `creditcard`, `date`, `email`, `eurodate`, `guid`, `social_security_number`, `ssn`, `telephone`, `time`, `URL`, `USdate`, `UUID`, `variableName`, `zipcode` (will be passed through to your CFML engine's `IsValid()` function).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<!--- Make sure that the user has entered a correct credit card ---> <cfset validatesFormatOf(property="cc", type="creditcard")>
<!--- Make sure that the user has entered an email address ending with the `.se` domain when the `ipCheck()` method returns `true`, and it's not Sunday. Also supply a custom error message that overrides the Wheels default one ---> <cfset validatesFormatOf(property="email", regEx="^.*@.*.se$", if="ipCheck()", unless="DayOfWeek() IS 1", message="Sorry, you must have a Swedish email address to use this website.")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property exists in the supplied list.

code.span: validatesInclusionOf(list [, properties, message, when, allowBlank, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).

td.code: [property] is not included in the list

tr.td: Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre: <!--- Make sure that the user selects either "Wheels" or "Rails" as their framework ---> <cfset validatesInclusionOf(property="frameworkOfChoice", list="wheels,rails", message="Please try again, and this time, select a decent framework!")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property matches the length requirements supplied. Use the `exactly`, `maximum`, `minimum` and `within` arguments to specify the length requirements.

code.span: validatesLengthOf([ properties, message, when, allowBlank, exactly, maximum, minimum, within, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
The exact length that the property value must be.
The maximum length that the property value can be.
The minimum length that the property value can be.
A list of two values (minimum and maximum) that the length of the property value must fall within.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<!--- Make sure that the `firstname` and `lastName` properties are not more than 50 characters and use square brackets to dynamically insert the property name when the error message is displayed to the user. (The `firstName` property will be displayed as "first name".) ---> <cfset validatesLengthOf(properties="firstName,lastName", maximum=50, message="Please shorten your [property] please. 50 characters is the maximum length allowed.")>
<!--- Make sure that the `password` property is between 4 and 15 characters ---> <cfset validatesLengthOf(property="password", within="4,20", message="The password length must be between 4 and 20 characters.")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property is numeric.

code.span: validatesNumericalityOf([ properties, message, when, allowBlank, onlyInteger, condition, unless, odd, even, greaterThan, greaterThanOrEqualTo, equalTo, lessThan, lessThanOrEqualTo ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
Specifies whether the property value must be an integer.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).
Specifies whether or not the value must be an odd number.
Specifies whether or not the value must be an even number.
Specifies whether or not the value must be greater than the supplied value.
Specifies whether or not the value must be greater than or equal the supplied value.
Specifies whether or not the value must be equal to the supplied value.
Specifies whether or not the value must be less than the supplied value.
Specifies whether or not the value must be less than or equal the supplied value.

code.pre: <!--- Make sure that the score is a number with no decimals but only when a score is supplied. (Tetting `allowBlank` to `true` means that objects are allowed to be saved without scores, typically resulting in `NULL` values being inserted in the database table) ---> <cfset validatesNumericalityOf(property="score", onlyInteger=true, allowBlank=true, message="Please enter a correct score.")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the specified property exists and that its value is not blank.

code.span: validatesPresenceOf([ properties, message, when, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre: <!--- Make sure that the user data can not be saved to the database without the `emailAddress` property. (It must exist and not be an empty string) ---> <cfset validatesPresenceOf("emailAddress")>

d:entry.p: Validates that the value of the specified property is unique in the database table. Useful for ensuring that two users can't sign up to a website with identical screen names for example. When a new record is created, a check is made to make sure that no record already exists in the database with the given value for the specified property. When the record is updated, the same check is made but disregarding the record itself.

code.span: validatesUniquenessOf([ properties, message, when, allowBlank, scope, condition, unless ])

tr.td: Name of property or list of property names to validate against (can also be called with the `property` argument).
Supply a custom error message here to override the built-in one.
Pass in `onCreate` or `onUpdate` to limit when this validation occurs (by default validation will occur on both create and update, i.e. `onSave`).

If set to `true`, validation will be skipped if the property value is an empty string or doesn't exist at all. This is useful if you only want to run this validation after it passes the @validatesPresenceOf test, thus avoiding duplicate error messages if it doesn't.
One or more properties by which to limit the scope of the uniqueness constraint.
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `true` validation will run).
String expression to be evaluated that decides if validation will be run (if the expression returns `false` validation will run).

code.pre:
<!--- Make sure that two users with the same screen name won't ever exist in the database (although to be 100% safe, you should consider using database locking as well) ---> <cfset validatesUniquenessOf(property="username", message="Sorry, that username is already taken.")>
<!--- Same as above but allow identical user names as long as they belong to a different account ---> <cfset validatesUniquenessOf(property="username", scope="accountId")>

d:entry.p: Returns an array of all the verifications set on this controller in the order in which they will be executed.
None.

code.pre: <!--- Get verification chain, remove the first item, and set it back ---> <cfset myVerificationChain = verificationChain()> <cfset ArrayDeleteAt(myVerificationChain, 1)> <cfset setVerificationChain(myVerificationChain)>

d:entry.p: Instructs Wheels to verify that some specific criterias are met before running an action.

code.span: verifies([ only, except, post, get, ajax, cookie, session, params, handler, cookieTypes, sessionTypes, paramsTypes ])

tr.td: List of action names to limit this verification to.
List of action names to exclude this verification from.
Set to `true` to verify that this is a `POST` request.
Set to `true` to verify that this is a `GET` request.
Set to `true` to verify that this is an AJAX request.
Verify that the passed in variable name exists in the `cookie` scope.
Verify that the passed in variable name exists in the `session` scope.
Verify that the passed in variable name exists in the `params` struct.
Pass in the name of a function that should handle failed verifications. The default is to just abort the request when a verification fails.
List of types to check each listed `cookie` value against (will be passed through to your CFML engine's `IsValid` function).
List of types to check each list `session` value against (will be passed through to your CFML engine's `IsValid` function).
List of types to check each `params` value against (will be passed through to your CFML engine's `IsValid` function).

code.pre:
<!--- Tell Wheels to verify that the `handleForm` action is always a `POST` request when executed ---> <cfset verifies(only="handleForm", post=true)>
<!--- Make sure that the edit action is a `GET` request, that `userId` exists in the `params` struct, and that it's an integer ---> <cfset verifies(only="edit", get=true, params="userId", paramsTypes="integer")>
<!--- Just like above, only this time we want to redirect the visitor to the index page of the controller if the request is invalid and show an error in The Flash ---> <cfset verifies(only="edit", get=true, params="userId", paramsTypes="integer", handler="index", error="Invalid userId")>

d:entry.p: Truncates text to the specified length of words and replaces the remaining characters with the specified truncate string (which defaults to "...").

tr.td: Number of words to truncate the text to.
String to replace the last characters with.

code.pre:
#wordTruncate(text="Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion", length=4)# -> Wheels is a framework...
#truncate(text="Wheels is a framework for ColdFusion", truncateString=" (more)")# -> Wheels is a framework for (more)

d:entry.p: Builds and returns a string containing a select form control for a range of years based on the supplied `name`.

code.span: yearSelectTag(name [, selected, startYear, endYear, includeBlank, label, labelPlacement, prepend, append, prependToLabel, appendToLabel ])

tr.td: Name to populate in tag's `name` attribute.
The year that should be selected initially.

Whether to include a blank option in the select form control. Pass `true` to include a blank line or a string that should represent what display text should appear for the empty value (for example, "- Select One -").
The label text to use in the form control.
Whether to place the label `before`, `after`, or wrapped `around` the form control.
String to prepend to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to prepend to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.
String to append to the form control's `label`. Useful to wrap the form control with HTML tags.

code.pre:
<!--- View code ---> <cfoutput> #yearSelectTag(name="yearOfBirthday", selected=params.yearOfBirthday)# </cfoutput>
<!--- Only allow selection of year to be for the past 50 years, minimum being 18 years ago ---> <cfset fiftyYearsAgo = Now() - 50> <cfset eighteenYearsAgo = Now() - 18> <cfoutput> #yearSelectTag(name="yearOfBirthday", selected=params.yearOfBirthday, startYear=fiftyYearsAgo, endYear=eighteenYearsAgo)# </cfoutput>
